story:
My name is Dustyn.  I am 34yrs old, and my business fell apart under the weight of our new economy.  As a result, I have decided to go to college, get an education and a degree, and make myself useful to society again.  I went online, researched universities, and met with a student advisor.  She told me what college would be, what to expect, and about all the loans and grants that were available to help me fund this endeavor.  Everything went to plan until I found out that of the potential $5550 per semester that was available through the Pell Grant, I would only be getting $300.  The reason I was only getting $300 instead of the $5550 was because I made too much money in 2009.  I found that hard to believe considering my tax returns showed me at barely $1500 above the poverty level, but I was assured that if I made over $9k/yr that I wouldn’t get anywhere near that potential.  My classes cost $550 per credit hour plus books, and I have to maintain at least 12hrs per semester to be considered full time (I want to do 16 or more).  If I don’t maintain those hours my loans will be reduced, and I may lose the $300 grant money completely.  As it is right now, it’s costing me over $1000/mo out of pocket to attend school, so I’ve turned to you for help, and this is why:

The same way having my business fall apart inspired me to go to school, having my grant money fall apart inspired me to search for more grants and scholarships.  I did my research, as I always do, and found many grants and scholarships.  The problem was, I didn’t qualify for any of them.  Still, that wouldn’t get me down.  However, I did start noticing things that were bothering me, so I researched further.

As it turns out, I don’t qualify for a “Multicultural Scholarship” because of my culture.  My first question was “How does a “culture” make a person “scholarly?”  Then I noticed what the qualifications were for this scholarship: It is available to all “non-Caucasians.”  This was an expected nuisance, but then I saw another scholarship, on the same page, that said it “wouldn’t be based on sex, color, race, creed, national origin, or any other illegal consideration.”  Why is it an illegal consideration for one scholarship and the entire basis for another one on the same page, from the same school?  That’s not even to mention all the scholarships and grants available to women.

I’m not a racist or a sexist.  Nor will I become one if I can’t afford school.  I understand that these grants were born of necessity in their day, and that the people that worked for them were striving for equality.  What no one seems to realize is that equality was never reached; they overshot the mark.  The ability to get an education is still based on race and sex unless you happen to be wealthy.  That’s how it’s always been throughout history, only the race and sex that are being discriminated against have changed.  As I researched more and more grants and scholarships, they are all aimed at high school students (which is understandable, so they can persuade them in), women, and minorities.  I assume it’s to persuade them in too, but do colleges really not want to persuade Caucasian men through their doors, or are they trying to imply that women and other ethnicities aren't as capable as Caucasian men, and therefore require the assistance?

I’m a good person that‘s trying to do something good, and I need your help.  Even if you can’t help me financially, please at least forward this link to your friends and post it on your Facebook page.  If I can double my goal (which is just enough to get me through the fall 2010 semester) by the deadline, I am going to try to start a nonprofit organization whose focus will be true equality in education.  Needless to say, donations of any size are not only helpful and appreciated, but help show the nation how many people are behind me on this.  Enough people will get media attention, and that’s the real way to get the changes made that bring equality.  Just $5 from 973 people will get me to my first goal; $10 from those same people will get all of us to my second goal.  Thank you for your contribution.

Sincerely,

Dustyn Arney

story:
Who is Wedu?

Wedu invests in high-potential young women from underprivileged backgrounds in South-East Asia to attend university, so they become changemakers in their communities.

Wedu is a registered UK Charity (No 1149494), founded in 2012 by Mario, Acumen Fund Fellow 2011 and Mari Sawai. We were proudly named Social Enterprise Startup of the Year 2012 at Cambridge University's Business Plan Competition. Made possible by a global team spanning three continents, we currently operate in Cambodia and Myanmar from our base in Bangkok, Thailand.

Why?

It all started... with encountering and pondering the following:

  • Forbes lists that only 2.4% of the US Fortune 500 CEOs in 2010 were female.
  • In places like Myanmar or Haiti, less than 5% of Members of Parliament are women.
  • In some Developing Countries like Afghanistan, the ratio of girls to boys in university is a meager 1 to 5.

Despite research showing that female leadership creates a more democratic society and higher gross national income, this disparity persists. Now consider how many talented women do not have access to college every year. How many potential future leaders would be among them? Leaders that would have the courage, passion, and brains to change the world around them?

Think there’s something wrong with the system? Wedu. 

Not only does attending university train critical minds for individual empowerment, it is also a life-changing experience to better the life of an individual as well as those in their communities.

There's more fabulous news: You can be part of all this! Not a superhero, not a queen, not a movie star. You.

JOIN US in nurturing the next generation of leaders – one student at a time! 

What do Wedu?

Our mission is to offer every high-potential leader the opportunity to instill change in their communities through powerful visions of positive change.

1- Find students with leadership potential and inspiring mentors using our network of field partners.

2- Provide:
• Empowering life-long mentorship: most programs focus on getting students through university. We believe that catalyzing the blossoming of an individual takes more than that! We are developing a lifelong mentoring community where each mentor has a role in a phase of the life of the future leader.
• Support to become a leader in business, government and civil society by providing leadership training and networking opportunities with remarkable individuals in the student’s field and country of interest.
• Better finance: Based on students future income potential we provide loans or enter into income sharing agreements which are:
o affordable for low interest rate, to minimize cost of capital,
o flexible, matching student’s cash flow,
o less risky, so student can focus on studies and leadership development. We match students’ risk profile with investors willing to bear that risk while investors can strike their balance between social and financial return.
And if the student is really great but can’t pay back we have also scholarships.
• Enhanced access: We partner with universities in emerging economies offering quality teaching at much lower cost than in OECD countries, guaranteeing high returns for graduates and minimizing brain drain.
• Administrative consulting: Assisting with university applications, entrance examinations, access to locally available scholarships and funding.


3- Incentivize students to return and give back by becoming mentors themselves and returning the funds received in our revolving fund to multiply impact while helping Wedu become sustainable.

We expect Wedu's students to become role models, a source of inspiration, and a pillar of our global support network for the generations to come.

 

Why do we need your contribution?

Because getting young women into university to install positive change in their communities requires some serious construction work. With $25,000 USD, we will build the critical infrastructure required to support young leaders in developing countries.

  • $10,000 USD for student loans

Student loans are a brand new concept in countries like Cambodia, with the power to unlock thousands of students' potential. This is why the biggest chunk of money will go to the audacious piloting of our student loan program. Up to 25 loans at $400 USD testing value will be provided through our partner Microfinance Insitutions in Cambodia. This equals the cost of one term for a master and one year of undergrad in Cambodia (vis-à-vis, e.g. an iPhone). 

  • $7,500 USD for the mentorship program and platform

We believe that mentorship is critical to support the personal development of young individuals with leadership potential. Mentorship provides a role model, inspiration and also knowledge about opportunities to develop one's potential. This is why are developing an on-line platform to connect mentor and mentees from all over the world. By seeking partnerships with experienced mentors, we aim to offer the most enriching experience for both mentor and mentee. 

  • $7,500 USD for an online fundraising platform

We would like you to be part of the Wedu-experience by offering financial and mentorship support to our students well beyond this campaign. This is why we are designing an online fundraising platform that offers Wedu's Education Angels (YOU!) a user-friendly, appealing, and efficient investment interface. Around 2x $3,000 USD will go into the fundraising engine and the portfolio interface. The remaining $1,500 USD are invested into mobile access design.

 

To reassure you that there is zero intention to squander your money, you may dial up the UK Charity Commission and inquire about Wedu, Charity No. 1149494:

+44 845 300 0218

They'll tell you what we are up to.

 

What's in it for You?

For any financial contribution, you'll get a fun and eccentric selection of perks, including: Immortality, Inspiration, Surprise, Involvement, PLUS the title of Associate Education Angel. Can you ask for more?

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you might feel more comfortable contributing in immaterial ways. We do understand. There's a plethora of other ways to get involved with Wedu, and your involvement is just as fabulous as any material donation. 

Want ideas?

  • Spread the word about your Wedu-Pride
  • Like us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter
  • Share your thoughts on how to make Wedu even better
  • Become a mentor for our students, or
  • Volunteer with us！

Your smallest contribution matters - remember, the world is for you to change and this campaign for you to share. Thank You!

 If still in doubt, meet Ly Chhay, our first student!

Mario and Mari met Ly Chhay on their first Wedu field trip to Cambodia. She comes from a village in rural Kampong Cham province. Thanks to Wedu, she is now a student at Asian University for Women in Chittagong, Bangladesh, where she managed to secure a full scholarship for her first year. You can see Ly Chhay in the picture on the right hand side with Ruby, one of our great Talent Spotters, before boarding her first flight!

Ly Chhay's story is an inspiring example of a promising girl whose dream has become a reality. Here we share her original letter to Wedu --  for your eyes only:

"I have a diamond opportunity to know Wedu through Khmer Youth Association which I had volunteered during high school for over three years, leading a group of youth to work and assist the community development. [...] I believe in Wedu and I trust I can do it. Since I was young I have imagined of flying to study abroad and back with enough ability to change and help my country”.

[...] Wedu is my power mentor. Wedu helped me with my process of my application and my journey going abroad. [...] When I was 6 years old I did not have even rice to eat and I was a garbage collector. But, I have never given up. I struggled with all these things step by step. Once I am accepted to university I was very excited and I relaxed for five minutes before telling my parents, they were happier and put their arms around me and say they are lucky to be my parents. That was a very beautiful day in my life. They cannot speak English, but they told me to thanks in advance for Wedu that help supporting me, because they have never thought that one of their daughters can fly to study abroad, as I am now."

Be inspired by the story of Ly Chhay and join us on our journey towards developing local changemakers. THANK YOU.

Questions/Suggestions? Reach out to the team on indiegogo(at)wedufund.org. We are happy to hear your feedback!

story:
About Me:

     My name is JayR deGuzman. I am a Performer/Teacher. I specialize in are Dance (Hip-hop and Locking), Tae Kwon Do, and Martial Arts Tricking/Acrobatics. I've been doing it for 8 years and have been able to perform and teach these skills around the U.S. I am involved with a non-profit organization called Soulciety that will be travelling back to the Philippines in January 2014 to provide education and resources to schools that are heavily affected by poverty, abuse, and negelect. This program is called The Bridge.

Video of my Skills: http://youtu.be/MYqgRb6FIlo

The Bridge Program

     The Bridge is an overseas educational mission and cultural immersion program that gives youth and young adults from the Bay Area and other parts of the U.S. an opportunity to provide resources and education to impoverished youth in different parts of the world. The program focuses on providing services and aid to the youth in the Philippines as they are in dire need of support.

     Issues in the Philippines include:

  • The Philippines is an international hotspot for human trafficking, ranking among the top five countries in the world where most human trafficking victims come from. An estimated 100,000 children are trafficked in the Philippines, most of which are forced to become sex slaves in China, Japan, Europe, the Middle East, and the U.S.
  • 40% of the Philippines' population (27.6 million people) lives under the poverty line. 1.4 million are street children.
  • 11% of children (2.2 million in 2001) are forced into labor.
  • 6 million children are malnourished

 

Our Goal

    With this program, our goal is to reach 8000 youth throughout the provinces of the Philippines by providing support and supplies to further their education and improve their health.

     Other program objectives include:

  • Providing 100 computers in order to build a minimum of 3 Computer Learning centers at schools and develop a computer literacy curriculum that will be taught to teachers to help youth reach their educational goals and prepare them for the work force
  • Promote Performing Arts education through music, dance, and poetry
  • Providing another 1000 pairs of shoes and promote proper footwear awareness
  • Provide another 5000 hygiene supplies such as toothbrushes, toothpaste, floss, shampoo, and soap and promote proper hygiene awareness
  • Provide another 5000 school materials such as backpacks, binders, and writing utensils to promote educational advancement

 

What exactly does the money go to?

     My main purpose for being involved is to help with the services and education that is being provided by the program. There will be about a total of 12-16 of us that will be travelling to the Philippines to educate and provide for the impoverish communities. Each individual is responsible for fundraising $3000 which will cover:

  • Flight: $1200
  • Lodging: $700
  • Transportation: $100
  • Food: $300
  • Daily Expenses: $400
  • Special Projects: $300

     In case my $3000 goal is not reached, I will not be able to travel to the Philippines to take part in the 2014 Bridge Program, but all funds raised will go towards coordinating the program.

 

The Bridge Program Over the Years

     Since 2009, The Bridge Program has reached over 20,000 youth in provinces throughout the Philippines including Batangas, Pampanga, Iloilo, Cebu, Boracay, Mindoro, Negros, and Behol. Soulciety has donated the following equipment and supplies directly to schools: 110 fully-functioning Pentium III+ computers, 8000 school materials, 13,000 hygiene supplies, 14,000 books, 1500 pairs of shoes, and boxes of medicine, clothes, sports equipment, and other materials.

 

Other Ways You Can Get Involved

Adopt-A-Computer Lab

     Soulciety will be donating another 100 computers to schools in the Philippines and will be teaching the teachers about the computer literacy so that they can, in turn, teach their students. You and/or your organization can adopt this project by raising or donating $5,000 to build a computer lab at a participating school. An existing classroom will be renovated and these renovations include:

  • tiling the floors
  • installing secure windows and doors
  • installing an air-conditioning system
  • re-wiring electricity and installing lights
  • installing internet access for atleast 3 years
  • building computer tables and benches for the students
  • hiring a project manager to manage the project

You will be recognized as an Official Sponsor and a plaque will be placed at the computer lab that you sponsor in honor of your support.

Donate Supplies

You and/or your organization can coordinate a donation drive at your school campus or facility to collect one of the following supplies:

  • School materials (binders, paper, backpacks, pencils, etc)
  • hygiene supplies (soap, shampoo, toothbrushes, toothpaste, floss)
  • Medicine & Supplies (aspirin, gauges, crutches, first aid)

These supplies will be donated directly to the children and schools in the provinces in the Philippines. Supplies must be submitted by July 31, 2013.

Thank you for taking your time to go through my campaign, and I hope you can help me make it to the Philippines next year!

http://www.soulciety.org

You and/or your organization can adopt this project by raising or donating $5,000 to build a computer lab at a participating school. An existing classroom will be renovated and these renovations include:

tiling the floors
installing secure windows and doors
installing an air-conditioning system
re-wiring electricity and installing lights
installing internet access for atleast 3 years
building computer tables and benches for the students
hiring a project manager to manage the project

You will be recognized as an Official Sponsor and a plaque will be placed at the computer lab that you sponsor in honor of your support.Donate Supplies
You and/or your organization can coordinate a donation drive at your school campus or facility to collect one of the following supplies:

School materials (binders, paper, backpacks, pencils, etc)
hygiene supplies (soap, shampoo, toothbrushes, toothpaste, floss)
Medicine & Supplies (aspirin, gauges, crutches, first aid)

These supplies will be donated directly to the children and schools in the provinces in the Philippines. Supplies must be submitted by July 31, 2013.Thank you for taking your time to go through my campaign, and I hope you can help me make it to the Philippines next year!http://www.soulciety.org

story:
Prayers on Wings - Who We Are

Our organization is the vision of Devin Nakasone, a childhood leukemia survivor.  Having to deal with major emotional issues in his teens and young adulthood, he later realized that they could be traced to the feelings of guilt, shame, and fear that he had unknowingly bottled up while his parents were focused on his physical survival.  During that time his best friend became a rubber duck.  Today his mission is to build bridges of communication between children in crisis and their loved ones, utilizing a simple rubber duck, because with proper communication, survival is easier.

This campaign is to help our rapidly growing organization obtain office space and equipment that will enable us to reach a larger number of people more quickly and efficiently.  We have the vision, but lack adequate equipment.  We hope with updated technology, we will be able to expand our reach to whoever needs our help.

What We Hope to Obtain with Funding

With full funding we hope to:
  • Rent office space for a year
  • Purchase video cameras and computers to record our workshop and events
  • Purchase Camera equipment
  • Hire a video editor to help us produce DVDs

To see some videos from our event please visit www.youtube.com/prayersonwings.  You will see why we are excited to purchase new equipment!

Perks

Perks include tshirts, copies of our DVD, and even our limited edition sterling silver and diamond custom logo pendants made specially for Indiegogo donors only, similar to the ones in photo below:

 

If you are not able to contribute, please share our campaign with your friends.  For more information our website is www.prayersonwings.webs.com.

story:
CU in South Africa!

UPDATE! We have confirmed our collaboration with several community organizers in the Maboneng Precinct of Johannesburg. While there, we will be helping a local creche (day care) with some projects and skills training. We are so excited to have established this new relationship and are pleased that their values of sustainability and community empowerment align with ours. Want to learn more about the amazing things these folks are doing? Check it out: http://youtu.be/Ndv9xIEYzlo

We are a group of 11 Carroll University (CU) students in Waukesha, Wisconsin, who are enrolled in a Cross Cultural Experience class focused on South Africa. Our coursework will culminate in two weeks immersion in South Africa this May, where we will experience the culture and history, see the beauty of the land and its people, and reflect upon the valuable lessons and meanings of South Africa's struggle for freedom and equality. 

But we are not only going to tour the country! We are in the process of building relationships with a Cape Town secondary school and organizations in Johannesburg's Maboneng precinct with whom we can volunteer while there. What makes this unique is that we strive to make these relationships sustainable, so that they will continue after we return to the US. We are excited to build lasting friendships and partnerships that will benefit all involved.

We are the FIRST class from CU going to Sub-Saharan Africa and we are asking you to help us make it successful! 

The view of Table Mountain on the ferry to Robben Island. 

Nelson Mandela was held prisoner for 18 of his 27 years in prison on Robben Island. While there, we will be led on a tour of the grounds by a former prisoner.

We are building a sustainable relationship with Groenvlei High School outside of Cape Town.

What We Need & What You Get

Let's face it, we can use all the help we can get! But we understand that resources for most of us are limited. That's why we are hoping that our circles of friends and families will band together to help. If each person donated even $10, it would add up fast! 

We are hoping to raise at least $1,000 by April 18 to help offset ground transportation costs while in South Africa. We also want to bring donations to our partners of school or office supplies, books, etc., depending on their needs. All financial contributions to this campaign will go to support the entire group (transportation, partner donations, etc.) and not used for personal expenses.

We invite you to take a look at our perks; they are our unique ways of saying thanks for your generous donations!

We will spend three nights at Rhino River Lodge observing the wildlife and learning about their conservation and anti-poaching efforts with local communities and authorities.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute financially, feel free to contact us to find out more about non-cash donations. In addition, please consider sending the campaign info to others who may have an interest. THANK YOU!!

We will visit the huge Zamimpilo Market. This is a cooperative market where the women sell their crafts to benefit their community and this is where your souvenirs will come from if you give $50 or more!

story:
The Musana Music Center

Musana, meaning light in Luganda, is an established music center in Mugongo. While it has taken many years for it to reach this level it now has a building of its own, a traveling and performing brass band and is an education center for younger musicians. The center is partnered with the The Uganda Baltimore Alliance (TUBA) that connects musicians from Baltimore with those in Uganda, that's where I come in..

Who I Am

My name is Liz Fryer. I am Peabody Conservatory graduate in French horn performance and music education. I love music, I love teaching, and I love working with the musicians in Uganda. However, being a student and wanting to make these passions a working reality means that I am going to need your help..

Who You Are

Today you are You, that is truer than true. There is no one alive who is Youer than You!

A little Dr. Seuss is always good for the soul :). 

Moving on! You are the person that can make all of this possible. By donating not only are you helping to fund my travel expenses, but if we are able to reach higher then the $2,500 goal then you are also putting money towards music, theory books, new instruments, repairs to current instruments, band uniforms (which they will look just marvelous in) and growing the organization so that this center can thrive and support itself. Uganda is a country that is struggling with high unemployment especially in youths, and contributions go towards giving these youth a job and also the ability to do something wonderful and take pride in it.

Now as I mentioned before this will be a return visit for me. A year and a half ago I went with two wonderful women, brass players, and close friends of mine and we had a fabulous life-changing experience that I cannot wait to have again! Instead of me going on and on about how great it was, please read this blog and some cool articles about the trip! Lots of information, pictures and funny stories. (Some of the names are different, but it is still the same group of people).

http://eebtrioinuganda.blogspot.com/2012/12/the-time-has-come.html

http://hub.jhu.edu/gazette/2013/february/peabody-brass-uganda

How You Can Help

Donating! That would just be fantastic, and any amount is helpful! Only have a dollar? That's fine! You'll be supporting a great cause!

Where the money goes:

  • Flight from JFK to Entebbe, Uganda and returning: $1,655.30
  • Airport lodging and transport: $110
  • Food: $100
  • Travel Insurance: $75
  • Visa and postage: $62
  • Medical Expenses: $110
  • Bedding: $100
  • Theory Books: $150
  • Pencils: $13
  • Phone and Internet access: $100
  • Local transport: $25

Please remember that your donation is tax deductible through Fractured Atlas!

Sharing! There are a bunch of buttons with little pictures of different places other people look, click the button! Spread the word! Make some noise! (not literal of course, but hey, shouting outside to support this could be helpful too!)

Giving! Old instruments? Old theory books/music? Extra brass care and cleaning supplies? All of this is welcome!! Email me if you would like to donate anything!

Lastly

You are a delightful person for reading this far. And you have the chance to help make a huge difference in somebody's life that could really use the joy of music, but to bring back that good ole Dr. Seuss..

“Unless someone like you cares a whole awful lot, Nothing is going to get better. It's not.”

story:
Short Summary

My Name is Valerie Nicole 18 years old and an immigrant in Canada from the Philippines i am a working self supporting student that is active in the community programs for the youth, equality for women and Hunger elimination. My campaign is to raise awareness of youth empowerment through supporting me in any way on kind or donations for this pageant that reflects the essence of being a responsible youth. Any amount will do and the magnitude of your help will go a long way to help the homeless and out of school youths  this will greatly help the community of Prince Albert in its quest to represent the best and the brightest.



  • Proceeds of the funding will go to Cardiac Kids Canada and the expenses to sponsor this fundraising event and the competition.
  • I am very active with the community services Seniors recreation, youth empowerment sports  recreation and the banner of programs promoting equality for women in the socioeconomic society. if the goal is not reached proceeds of which go to Typhoon Haiyan victims in the Philippines.


Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  •  use e indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary


Mission

The primary mission of the Center for Effective English Language Teaching is to develop a program that will function to increase the teaching skills of those who wish to teach the English language.  The outcome for those who do fully participate is to significantly enhance the likelihood of life enhancement, through their work life and other significant aspects of daily interaction . This will be true for themselves and those they end up teaching.  The emphasis on causing the program be a part of Empowering Women is a clear component within it.  There will also be outreach to those men and women who may have disabilities,


FOUNDER HISTORY

In the years 1999-2001 I was a Peace Corps volunteer in the country of Uzbekistan.  During that time I was a co-founder of a program called the Institute for English Language Teacher Education.  That program still exists and still functions as a door of opportunity for the Teachers and Students who participate within it.  Many now teach English in other lands or in Uzbekistan.  In short, the program still functions to be a catalyst for increased communication and interaction throughout the world.  Indeed, there has been the ripple effect that can happen through education.  

ABOUT THE PROGRAM

A similar need exists within the countries of Southeast Asia.  In fact, English has been designated as the official language for the countries in the Association of Southeastern Asian Nations (ASEAN).  The program for which this funding campaign is being created is designed to to enhance the likelihood of effective/useful English language learning.  A net result of that will be to, again, foster international communication and, simultaneously, increase opportunity for those involved.  The program will have specific outreach to Women as a part of the recognized need for more Women's Empowerment.  Additionally, we will be reaching out to those with Disabilities who might participate either as a Teacher or a Student.

The funds for this part of Start-up (those derived from this Indiegogo campaign) will be primarily aimed at the costs associated with finding the original Teachers (5-10 teachers) who will constitute the corps Staff for future involvement as Trainers.  These teachers will then be trained as continuing Teacher Trainers. This training will, at least initially, be in Thailand

I intend to use video and other communication means to inform all who wish to know about the progress the program will have.

The program, in a way similar to the one in Uzbekistan will also be seeking other funding and will also endeavor to be essentially self-sustaining.      


What We Need & What You Get

Details of Proposed Funding Usage:

1.  Travel to destinations within Myanmar, Cambodia, Laos and Vietnam. Costs will include transportation, likely Air Asia or other discount carrier. Hotel nights (in economy hotel), usually two or three nights.  Meals, for the interviewers and interviewees.

2. Start-up equipment and supplies, to include.

                     A dedicated computer

                     start-up textbooks and other materials 

                     One part-time staff member.

PERKS

In general the "perks" to be received for contribution to the program will reflect my wish to have individuals who have an interest in the progress of the program, over time.

Thus, those who contribute can expect:

Video updates of that progress

Postcards and other means of personal updating  


USE OF FUNDS SHOULD WE NOT REACH OUR GOAL:  Expenses related to teachers selected for training would be the most important designation for use of funding.



Other Ways You Can Help

   To all who know me, if you cannot contribute, believe me I understand.  But, if you could pass this word along to those you might know who would be willing to help, this will gain my heartfelt thanks also.:  Please take note that Indiegogo has "Share tools" within this site, to help you spread the word to those with whom you wish to share.

story:
Who We Are

Detroit Arts Immersion provides performing arts workshops to abuse/neglect, long-term foster and paroled youth in Detroit.  Founded in 2009 by Juilliard Alum, Breanna O'Mara, we work to engage local artists and university students by giving training and teaching experience, in order to create longevity for arts programming in Detroit. 

As a group of young artists, we will work to share our tools in order to provide classes promoting ensemble work, creativity, self-expression, esteem and pride.  Using our disciplines of dance, drama, music and visual art, we will offer multiple avenues for expression and learning while enforcing team/ensemble work through collaborative, inter-disciplinary teaching.  

Over the past six years we have witnessed moments of growth, laughter and pure human beauty.  The youth who participate are overwhelmingly brave and dedicated to changing their current position, working to create a future they desire.  With your help we can continue to provide the highest quality workshops possible with access to proper supplies and complete lesson plans!

What We Need 

We are a volunteer based program.  The teachers work for the experience and what they get back from the students.  

Still, most of our teachers are attending university and we are committed to the fact that no one should be in the hole for sharing their knowledge and time.  

All funds will go to help pay for:

  • Supplies for lessons (notebooks, pens, paint, music, etc)
  • Travel expenses for teaching artists
  • Lunch for teaching artists

Why?

Once a cultural haven, Detroit is still a city of creativity and astonishing talent, but it is also one of hard times, economically and socially.  

The quality of life for many is low and the economic inequality high.  Opportunities are difficult to come by if you lack proper education.  

The youth we work with are between the ages of 18-24 and for various reasons have found themselves homeless.  Many are working to gain their GEDs, find a job and create a new better life for themselves.  Our work aims to build trust, confidence and communication while encouraging creative thought.  The tools learned are helpful in the job market, in one's community and in personal life.  


For more information please visit us at www.detroitartsimmersion.org

story:
Short Summary

Kayla (6 years old) and Syrenitee (4 years old) are modeling in the Planning Your Success fashion show to raise funds for their scholarship program. Now celebrating it's tenth year, Planning Your Success Chicago seeks to provide financial assistance, college and career advisement, and self-image counseling to high school students living within the city of Chicago, IL. Since its inception in 2004, the program has awarded over $20,000 in scholarships to students that have enrolled in various universities such as: The University of Illinois at Urbana- Champaign, Columbia College, Hampton University, Malcolm X College and several other institutions. The typical scholarship recipient is a first-generation college student that comes from a low-income household and demonstrates leadership, accountability, and integrity.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We've set the minimum Indiegogo goal of $500, but with YOUR help we can go above and beyond supporting this great cause!
  • Our awesome perks include: a personalized Video Shout Out, an actual ticket to the show for our local supports, handwritten thank you notes, and a DVD copy of the show for you to keep! Your favorite little models have been practicing for weeks and are so excited to make their runway debut!
  • Even if the goal is NOT met, ALL proceeds directly benefit the scholarship fund

The Impact

  • Now in it's tenth year, the program coordinator and support team of Planning Your Success work to assist students by fostering a mindset to become successful in accomplishing all of their college, career, and personal goals.
  • Services provided include tutoring, resume reviews, career coaching, and assistance navigating the college application process.
  • Again, the typical scholarship recipient is a first-generation college student that comes from a low-income household and demonstrates leadership, accountability, and integrity.

Any donation towards supporting this inspiring cause is greatly appreciated. Remember, even if you're unable to make a donation, please spread the word!

Short SummaryKayla (6 years old) and Syrenitee (4 years old) are modeling in the Planning Your Success fashion show to raise funds for their scholarship program. Now celebrating it's tenth year, Planning Your Success Chicago seeks to provide financial assistance, college and career advisement, and self-image counseling to high school students living within the city of Chicago, IL. Since its inception in 2004, the program has awarded over $20,000 in scholarships to students that have enrolled in various universities such as: The University of Illinois at Urbana- Champaign, Columbia College, Hampton University, Malcolm X College and several other institutions. The typical scholarship recipient is a first-generation college student that comes from a low-income household and demonstrates leadership, accountability, and integrity. What We Need & What You Get
We've set the minimum Indiegogo goal of $500, but with YOUR help we can go above and beyond supporting this great cause!
Our awesome perks include: a personalized Video Shout Out, an actual ticket to the show for our local supports, handwritten thank you notes, and a DVD copy of the show for you to keep! Your favorite little models have been practicing for weeks and are so excited to make their runway debut! 
Even if the goal is NOT met, ALL proceeds directly benefit the scholarship fund

The Impact
Now in it's tenth year, the program coordinator and support team of Planning Your Success work to assist students by fostering a mindset to become successful in accomplishing all of their college, career, and personal goals. 
Services provided include tutoring, resume reviews, career coaching, and assistance navigating the college application process. 
Again, the typical scholarship recipient is a first-generation college student that comes from a low-income household and demonstrates leadership, accountability, and integrity. 
Any donation towards supporting this inspiring cause is greatly appreciated. Remember, even if you're unable to make a donation, please spread the word!

story:
WE THANK YOU ALL WHO CONTRIBUTED AND PROMOTED THIS CAMPAIGN.

With the continued electricity interruptions in the district of Kabale in Uganda, the ongoing project of training people in acquiring computer basic skills has been frustrated heavily.

As a result a need for laptop computers that can save and store electricity and enable facilitation to the training to continue on daily basis.

The project is the brain work of members of the working class here in Kabale Uganda who are human rights activists as well as Industrial Workers of the World members and is targeted at enabling the same who are not yet computer literate so that they are able to at least use computers in typing and printing data,using internet to send and receive data and related skills.The laptop computers will also be used and enable the activists’ group to carry out mobile training workshops.

We need at least two laptop computers each valued at an equivalent of USD 400 thus totaling to a minimum of USD 800.

The computers will remain property of the whole group when the training is over.

Maximum transparency and accountability to be adhered to in the project.Copies of receipts,photos and other documents of the project to be sent to the project supporters and any person wishing so.

More photos and video clips are in the gallery section of the campaign

story:
Pearl is Autistic. And she is a blessing. Over the past few years our family has battled to get her the best education possible. There's been sleepless nights, arguments, and much stress. Mostly though, there has been much joy. The joy of watching her grow, learn, and conquer all that she faces is beyond inspiring.

At six-years-old she is now at the most pivotal time in her education, the next six years will form the woman that she will become. Whether she is a success or a statistic depends on what we do NOW. This means a private education and that means funding. When I ran across Ireland back in 2011 we raised enough for her to attend school and go on trips that she would not normally have participated in. I have had less time to run recently and that is because I have been on the ground, doing real Autism work. But there is one story I would like to share with you. After I ran across Ireland I was talking to a friend in London who had donated thirty pounds to the cause. He said to me, "Mally, anytime I think of the progress that your little girl makes, I know I directly contributed to that." He is right, he made her life different, just like you can do the same.

We are asking for donations of all sizes before she starts her new school on April 28th. Our aim is 2,000 euros. What you will receive in return is changing a little girls life. This is not hyperbole, you will change her life in every way imaginable. Her social, written, reading, and life skills will benefit from her new program. Having been at the new school yesterday with her mum I can tell you the new system is comprehensive and run by the best people around. Please consider this as not just a donation but an investment. Thank you for your generousity. On behalf of Pearl and the McLoughlin family.

Sincerely,

Malcolm McLoughlin.

story:
The Foundation for Positive Education is a non-profit status seeking organization looking to fund a Saturday school initiative for Black youth.



The Foundation strives to address issues of social inequality through innovative, community-based educational programs. Our mission is to assist and empower people in lower socio-economic, educationally underserved communities, transforming them into economically viable, socially stable, and academically rich neighborhoods. 

.  

The Saturday school initiative has been in existence since September 2004 (under another separate non-profit) , serving elementary school students, ages 6ï¿½14, and offering service learning opportunities to high school students, ages 14ï¿½18. Our primary objective is to enhance academic achievement. This is accomplished by improving youthï¿½s basic attitudes toward learning and school. Providing an affirming environment through positive role modeling, volunteers help youth understand social responsibility to their communities as well as the importance of collective work. The Foundation hopes through these general approaches to encourage cultural awareness, social consciousness, and future leadership within their communities.

 

The Foundation empowers youth specifically through reading and math skill development. A self-designed curriculum focusing on global contributions by Black people exposes youth to their cultural history. Creative arts and educational field trips will also be used to enhance academic performance; the variety of creative arts in which youth participate include writing, drawing, music, dancing, capoeira (martial arts), and culinary arts. Field trips include educational and cultural events throughout Chicago. The range of experiences that will be afforded to our youth truly compares to none.

This initiative did exist under a separate non-profit but is venturing out on its own. The Foundation's ambition is to generate sufficient resources necessary to start up programming again. The funds would be used for start-up cost (i.e. 501c3 status filing cost, program advertisement, materials, etc.)

story:
Short Summary

The purpose of the organization is to support poor Guatemalan youth, i.e., for the most part, descendants of the ancient Maya, in the pursuit of an education to first-world standards in the United States. Job training is not the object. Neither is the immediate relief of poverty. Rather, the organization seeks to give its direct beneficiaries an opportunity to acquire the knowledge of history and world affairs, of politics and jurisprudence, of philosophy and economics, and of science, literature, and the arts to enable them to transform the conditions in which their forebears have traditionally lived. In short, the organization’s objective is the creation of a cadre of knowledgeable leaders, of thinkers and writers, of professionals and entrepreneurs, in sufficient numbers to effect significant socio-economic development in Guatemala.
 
John Bodoh found the organization in 2003 after traveling and teaching in Guatemala. As a result of his experiences he was persuaded that the educational system of Guatemala is inadequate to the task of bringing the poor out of poverty and then conceived a plan for bringing some of them to the U.S. for part of their education. With no experience in non-profit organizations he struggled to find a way to bring his vision to reality. His heroic efforts paid off with the formation and growth of the Guatemalan Student Support Group.

What We Need & What You Get

GSSG pays all major expenses for the Guatemalan students: passport, visa, airfare, major clothing, medical, dental, and eye care, tuition, books and school supplies.

The students live with host families who provide room and meals as well as a supportive atmosphere.

Donors provide all the financial resources for GSSG. Supporting a child in high school costs GSSG about $7,500 per year and in college the costs jump to about $30,000 per year.  You can become a part of this effort by helping toward the cost of one high school student. Any donation will be acknowledged with much gratitude.

The Impact

We, at the GSSG, feel that the existence of a middle class is an essential element in the business environment of a modern democracy, the dearth of such a class in the socioeconomic structure of Guatemala is the chief cause of that country’s social, political, and economic dysfunction. Our program to develop Guatemala’s middle class through the education of a cadre of promising Guatemalan youth serves not only the citizenry of Guatemala but U.S. interests as well and is eminently replicable throughout Latin America.  

Our program has other benefits in addition to helping improve socioeconomic conditions in Guatemala. GSSG will help reduce the destructive effect of emigration to the USA on the Guatemalan society, and, through the development of personal, professional, and state friendships, diminish the likelihood of violence involving USA interests abroad.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to do more, you can also partially sponsor a Guatemalan student during his educational years in the USA. Sonsorships start as low as $25 per month. You will receive information about your child's background, school progress, and will have the opportunity to communicate with the student by mail if you wish.

If you can't contribute please tell your family and friends about the GSSG and its mission.

story:
My goal for this fundraising campaign is to create application(s) that will assist coaches of youth sports to manage the external interruptions such as play counts, player management, play development, and play integration so that the behind the scenes process is streamlined and coaches can reassign their time to the full attention of the kids that they coach. This in turn can maximize the impact and educational value that they intend to furnish upon the children. If we are able to raise the funds associated with application development, which often reach thousands of dollars, needing application designers, developers, and programmers, we would like to work with local and national youth sports organizations to implement these applications to assist youth coaches everywhere. Primarily our focus right now is youth football, but with the changes in technology and the assistance it can provide, we see the opportunity to implement applications across youth sports. This goal is in line with using youth sports as an outlet for children to learn, grow, and become positive contributing members of society.

As the costs for procuring the tools and devices needed in order to develop, test, and release the applications can be exceedingly costly we are looking for individuals to donate funds to assist in our efforts. Once we have reached our goal we can purchase our way into the Apple development community gaining the platform necessary to develop the applications. Through the use of the tools, membership, as well as educational material we will be able to begin the developing and programming aspect of the project.

This in turn can maximize the impact and educational value that they intend to furnish upon the children. If we are able to raise the funds associated with application development, which often reach thousands of dollars, needing application designers, developers, and programmers, we would like to work with local and national youth sports organizations to implement these applications to assist youth coaches everywhere. Primarily our focus right now is youth football, but with the changes in technology and the assistance it can provide, we see the opportunity to implement applications across youth sports. This goal is in line with using youth sports as an outlet for children to learn, grow, and become positive contributing members of society.
As the costs for procuring the tools and devices needed in order to develop, test, and release the applications can be exceedingly costly we are looking for individuals to donate funds to assist in our efforts. Once we have reached our goal we can purchase our way into the Apple development community gaining the platform necessary to develop the applications. Through the use of the tools, membership, as well as educational material we will be able to begin the developing and programming aspect of the project.

story:
Not Your Typical "SEX ED"

I am a sexologist (Ph.D. Candidate, Human Sexuality, M.Ed. Human Sexuality, B.A. Sexuality, Marriage, and Family) and I believe that 1. Sex should be fun 2. Pleasure is good for you 3. Everyone should be free to enjoy their sexuality without fear of violence.

I relay this message to college students via workshops that are empowering, sex-positive, pleasure-focused, and fun. Topics include:

  • The Female Orgasm
  • How to Feel Sexy Naked
  • Safer and Sexy
  • Sex: Am I Normal?
  • Ask the Sexologist
  • The Politics of Sexual Oppression
  • The 21 Year Old Entrepreneur
  • Being an LGBT Ally
  • and more!

It's not uncommon for students in my workshops to move from laughter, to life-changing introspection, to happy tears, in a one hour presentation. Due to such a response, colleges ALWAYS invite me back, many inviting me back each semester (twice per year) to speak and present one of my workshops. However this year I'm finding that colleges and universities have had their budgets slashed, and many student clubs and organizations that normally use my services have a prohibitively low budget or no budget at all.

Your contribution will bring my sex-positive, holistic, and comprehensive sex education programs to college students who no longer have speaker budgets.

What I Need & What You Get

My workshops cost $1,000. If I reach my $3,000 goal that will mean that three colleges can have access to sex-positive education at no cost to them. Or, 4, 5, 6,  or more colleges with small budgets that can contribute part of the cost can have access to sex-positive education at a subsidized rate.

As a thank you for your contribution, I'm offering some sexy perks for folks who contribute at the $5, $25, $50, $100, and $200 level.
 
  • $5- A shout out on my blog "A Day in the Life of a Sexologist", explaining how awesome you are and how you support sexual health and wellness.
  • $25- a handwritten thank-you note AND a shout out on my blog.
  • $50- a mystery item from my sex grab bag. Could be a bottle of lubricant, sex toy, or a quirky novelty AND a handwritten thank-you note, AND a shout out on my blog.
  • $100- a delightful bottle of clit cream, also known as "God's gift to women" AND a handwritten thank-you note AND a shout out on my blog.
  • $200- my eternal gratitude, a signed copy of my book "Fighting the Crusade Against Sex: Being Sex-Positive in a Sex-Negative World" AND ALL OF THE ABOVE!

The Impact

I have taught over 5,000 college students the importance of why sex should be fun, pleasure is good for you, and everyone should be able to enjoy their sexuality without fear of violence.

This is important work because today's college students completely missed out on sex education during their entire adolescence, as they were in middle and high school during the "abstinence-only" education mandate. Here are some quick stats from my college audiences in the past:

  • Approximately 90% didn't know the difference between a vulva and a vagina before my Female Orgasm workshop. What does that say about the way we view female sexuality in our culture if no one know or cares what the thing is called?
  • Approximately 85% didn't know that you can get STIs like herpes and HPV from unprotected oral sex before my Safer and Sexy workshop.
  • Approximately 60% couldn't name a single thing they liked about themselves before my How to Feel Sexy Naked workshop. 98% could after my workshop.

I don't want to focus on the pre-workshop detriments because that is never the focus of my presentations, which is probably why they work so well. I do these workshops to increase positives, not necessary decrease negatives. So for me, the impact is that a student has an empowered, shame-free understanding of their sexuality when they walk out and they are ready to pay it forward with compassion and sensitivity as they encounter other sexualities in the world.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute today, please pass along the word about my campaign on facebook, tumblr, and the like. If you've attended one of my college workshops in the past, let people know why you think this is a worthy cause, and the impact the knowledge I provided has had on you!

story:
The Idea
It all started with the idea of teaching leadership through photography. What would happen if a dozen middle schoolers who never used cameras got a summer to take pictures of their families and neighborhood? What if you used photography as a means to talk about leadership, what if a camera lens became a new way to see your neighborhood and understand your place within?

Then the idea met Chelsea and Brandon. They live and work in St. John’s, a neighborhood just north of downtown Austin. Chelsea worked with kids everyday, and knew just the ones who might embrace the experiment. So the  ideas got together, grabbed coffee, and this project was brewed.


The Goal
A six-week community development curriculum emerged. It had two parts.

1) To show middle schoolers their leadership potential, train them, and give them responsibility as counselors at a week long elementary summer camp.

2) To reinforce the students' understanding of themselves as change agents. Through teaching them basic photography we've shown them a new way to view their neighborhood and given them the chance to see themselves as leaders who can make a difference.


The Need
So now we need your help. We had the digital cameras donated. Pizza's been subsidized, but we want to throw a gala and show the students their hard work paid off. We're planning a gallery to display their shots and tell their stories. It will kick off a Fall series that continues to talk about the students and their neighborhood.

Austin Stone's generously offered us space on the wall of the St. John's campus to display a picture and short biography from each student. Getting these printed isn't cheap. Then we're hoping to give each student a photo book with the pictures they and their classmates shot this summer. We need your generosity to make that possible. Here's the breakdown.

  • Prints - $100 (10 pictures x $10 prints)
  • Frames - $100 (10 pictures x $10 frames)
  • Photo Books - $200 (10 students x $20 books)
  • Food & Beverages - $25
  • IndieGoGo Fees and Reward Costs - $75 (Kickstarter 5%, CC 3%)

If we raise more than $500 we'd love to spread the word about class to more folks in Austin. We've spoken with area coffee shops that are happy to display their work, but that will cost more money to print. If we cover that, we'd love to buy cameras for the students to own ($40 with batteries and memory card).

So chip in, at any level. And tell your friends online about the class as well. Thanks so much for making this project a reality!

The Links

Check out our weekly class blog
See the students' photos ($30 donors and up, pick your favorite)
See Lauren's Awesome Photo Skillz

story:
PBKS makes a difference in the lives of those in need

The PBKS drop-in centre provides people with food and drink, medical advice, spiritual and religious guidance and a safe space to be in. 

To bring away your child from dangerous streets even if it is just for a day. To have a chance to sleep for a few hours on a bed instead of a collapsed cardboard box in a dark smelly alley. To bathe and wash clothes. To talk to another person without fear of violence or being robbed. Basically a chance for them to feel human again.

After more than 7 years of serving the Chow Kit community of urban poor and socially marginalised in the heart of Kuala Lumpur, the Pusat Bantuan Khidmat Sosial (PBKS) or Social Assistance and Services Centre is now facing closure due to the abrupt discontinuation of Malaysian government funding.

Once touted by the World Health Organization (WHO) and the United Nations Development Program (UNDP) as an example of smart partnership between government and civil society organisations, the drop-in centre has played a critical role in ensuring that the Chow Kit community has access to HIV and AIDS education, prevention, care and support, and sexuality awareness and empowerment programmes for vulnerable sexual communities in Kuala Lumpur.

PBKS, previously managed by PT Foundation, is now managed by SEED (Social and Enabling Environment Development), a non-profit community driven organization staffed by members of the communities themselves. We seek to empower individuals to make a difference in their lives by standing on their own two feet and believing that their lives can change for the better.

PBKS works directly with communities of sex workers, transgender persons and People Living with HIV and their families in the Chow Kit area who depend on the essential daily services provided by the centre.

PBKS is a place where discrimination, stigma, feelings of loneliness and isolation can be left at the door. 

This is one of our stories:


This is what PBKS does:

Overall, in 2013, more than 35 000 lives came into contact with the drop in center and its outreach activities.  There were more than 3,000 visits by persons living with HIV. Around 4,500 walk-ins by those who are transgender. And almost 6,000 by women and girls who identified themselves as sex workers. 

Every person deserves a chance. Nobody is turned away. All are welcome.  

For many, PBKS is a place for solace, comfort, safety and a chance to not worry about where your next meal is going to come from. It is a place where we believe in hope.


But now, it is likely that the Drop In Centre will have to close its doors.

The Ministry of Women, Family and Community Development has decided not to continue its support of PBKS and its services from 2015 onwards. It was only last week that PBKS was informed of this decision.

We have heard the voices loud and clear from the community which say that they need PBKS. We are committed, passionate and steadfast in fighting to ensure that the doors stay open for those most in need and the lives we reach out to.

But we need your help. We need you to help us make it through the first six months of 2015.


What we need

The PBKS needs USD 35 000 to make it through till June 2015. 

It will go towards supporting the premises in Chow Kit, Kuala Lumpur and providing essential services to the surrounding community for a period of 6 months.

We need all the support and generous donations you can give in order for us to stay open.


Risks & Challenges


The amount we need will allow us some breathing room to explore and secure new long term funding without compromising our services to the people who depend on us.

It will not be easy. But we are committed to making it happen and to continue to keep hope and humanity alive in the dark corners of Chow Kit.

Help us in making a difference in the lives of those in need.

story:
Our Story

Discrimination has always been an overbearing issue in today’s society. It has plagued the world since the beginning of time and still runs rampant today. Many throughout history have tried and managed to lie down and defeat a small bit of discrimination, yet no one has been able to combat it as a whole. Yet, in Oakland, CA, one small organization plans to combat the age old ideas of prejudice and culture discrimination with the new age youth coming into the world.

The Mosaic Project draws from all demographics of 4th and 5th graders to create a diverse group to show how diverse the whole really is. Mosaic’s goal is to show these young people that they can combat discrimination in the world as they grow and become leaders and members of society. They work to break down social barriers to create a world that is void of hate based on differences, whether it be gender, sexual orientation, religion, race, culture or any other differences that exist today. They “have created a microcosm of the diverse, inclusive, just world we want to see and show [our] young subtends that peace is possible.



The Impact

The Mosaic Project sponsors low income students to attend their outdoor school, giving them an opportunity they may have not had. But being a non-project they have no additional in come to fund these students. The money they use for this cause comes from donations. But this isn't the only cause that your donation helps, less than 10% of income goes to administrative fees, less than 15% goes to fundraising to continue sponsoring students, and the other 75% or more is used to continue the program.

You can check out really touching videos of The Mosaic Project with their youth explaining what they thought of the program before they experienced it and what they thought of the program after they experienced it at http://www.mosaicproject.org/videos

Now that I’ve gone to Mosaic,

I know peace is

possible. JACK, AGE 11



What We Need & What You Get

Our campaign is trying to raise $500 for The Mosaic Project, but we need your help! All the donations will go directly to the Mosaic Project whether we reach the full amount or not. Your contributions will help the Mosaic Project hugely by providing the youth with a better experience with the new materials and diverse youth that will have the opportunity to go.



Other Ways You Can Help

You can donate directly to The Mosaic Project website at www.mosaicproject.org or you can go to their "Get Involved" section at http://www.mosaicproject.org/getinvolved to be a part of the community.  If you are a High School student you can also volunteer as a Youth Leader and be a part of the community that way.

story:
Mission Trip to Colombia

Christian Life Fellowship will be working with their sister church, Christian Life, in Colombia. This area is an impoverished community. The ministry of Christian Life extends beyond their four walls and into their neighborhood where the children of prostitutes are reached weekly with the Gospel through acts of kindness and biblical teaching.

VOX, our youth group, will be hosting an entire week of VBS for these children. My daughter is excited to be a part of this. Please give your support by participating in this exciting campaign. Any financial help, large or small, is greatly appreciated! Be blessed.

story:
Short Summary

Hi, I'm Freddie Lambright, III and I was born and raised in the Northern California Bay Area in Oakland and Berkeley. I graduated from the Oakland School for the Arts Visual Arts Program in June, 2013.  I am a freshman at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago (SAIC).

I've been drawing seriously since fourth grade and want to become a professional illustrator.  I've watched my techniques improve over the years and I'm excited about my talent and potential.  I believe that I have a special gift to offer the world.  My art positively contributes to social justice and helping people discover their uniqueness through exposure to my artwork.  Your contributions will help fund my college education at SAIC as I major in Illustration and double minor in Business and Art History.

I invite you to contribute to my multi-phase project, a unique concept called "The Royal Suite," which is a series of illustrations starting with the premier piece shown here, Queen of Clubs, or as I call them Clovers.  She rules the human kingdom and is also the Queen Bee.

I haven't yet finalized whether the next few pieces will complete the other Queens in the suits of Hearts, Diamonds, and Spades OR if I'll complete the rest of the suit of  Clovers, i.e. King, Jack, and Ace OR another combination.  It depends on which way my creative juices are flowing.  Ultimately, you'll be able to collect favorite pieces in a series or in a suit.  Stay tuned as more beautiful, impressive, and outstanding work from the project will be on the way over the course of the year.  And ... please tell a friend or two about my work so we can all spread the word.  It's an exciting and ambitious project.

  • Campaign Description and Why It's Important to Me.
My campaign is to create a new body of art work over the course of my college career that people can track and collect as I complete pieces in the series. This is Afro-Futuristic art, which intrigues me and allows for great creativity and artistic expression.  Hopefully you will be able to witness my growth and development as an artist as the pieces in the project evolve.  Contributors are supporting my growth and excellence in art as my techniques develop, expand, and become enhanced.

This campaign is important to me because it will help fund my college education and my dreams of becoming a professional illustrator. This campaign is essential for my continued attendance at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago.

This campaign is also important to me as I build a new portfolio of works and a cohesive series of art pieces. This campaign will enable me to create a new college level portfolio, while simultaneously securing needed funding for college.


  • Please Help Me to Get Closer to My Dreams.
By funding my project you will help a young, exceptionally talented, African-American man attend the School of the Art Institute of Chicago and pursue his dreams of becoming a professional illustrator. This project will help provide much needed funding for my tuition for spring semester.  My first semester at SAIC is going well and I really want to continue.

I’m going to college in a beautiful city that is known for being a cultural and artistic hub, which will greatly influence and develop my art skills and talents. By supporting my Queen of Clovers Campaign, and others in the Royal Suite Project, you will also help me get my name out in the world as an artist. I love for people to see and appreciate my art because I enjoy sharing my creative vision with others. I want more people to see my talent and potential.  By funding my campaign, you will become a part of my community to help showcase my talent and skill, and help encourage and empower a young talented brother with competence and vision.  Together we can make a positive difference in the world, which is so needed.

What We Need & What You Get

Breaking it down for ya'll in more detail:

We actually need almost $13,000 to help fund my college education for the remainder of this school year, but we're targeting half of that to start in this campaign. It would be great to exceed our goal and put us closer to our actual target amount needed.

The total cost of my education this academic year is about $57,000. I've been blessed so far to have received multiple scholarships from the Bacon Family foundation, the East Bay College Fund, Oakland Center for Spiritual Living, and School of the Art Institute of Chicago.  We're in application for a Marcus Foster Brotherhood scholarship, as well as one relating to Afro Futuristic art which fits perfectly with my artistic interests as I mentioned earlier.  We'll also be applying soon for more scholarship for the next academic year.  We need all the help we can get, including your thoughtful and generous support.

My family hosted my first solo artist showcase on August 17, 2013 before leaving for college as a fundraiser event, where I displayed 14 pieces, some of which were already sold and others I sold at the event.  The event went very well.  We took the opportunity at the art show to highlight this online fundraising campaign and unveiled the original Queen of Clovers, which was very well received.

I am so grateful for all donations - small, medium and large - as the money you contribute to this project will further fund my educational expenses this year.  I hope to launch at least one art campaign per semester that I'm at SAIC to continue this important fundraising activity for my continuation in college, as well as to continue to gain exposure and grow my reputation as a successful visual artist. This will also incent me to complete the Royal Suite Project, which is an exciting original concept that I'm very proud of.  By contributing to my campaign, you will be on the cutting edge of my budding art career.  Just think, you will be able to say "I knew him when and I supported him from the very start of his college career!  Look at him now!"

 - Perks!!

For this campaign, contributors get perks based on the featured piece - Queen of Clovers - and the level of contribution.  Subsequent campaigns will work similarly.   I will later publish the timeline of when I will be finishing individual pieces and suits in the larger scheme of the project.  Queen of Clovers is finished; I will finish other pieces for next campaigns as soon I can realistically during my school schedule.  The perks will be distributed within a reasonable time frame of the campaign.

  • Describe where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.
I have total faith in the Universe that I will reach my entire goal with the help and generous financial support of people like you.  All funds, regardless of if more or less than the ultimate goal, will go towards funding my college education at SAIC.

  •  Why is my project valuable to the contributor and to the world.
Funding my campaign will get my name out into the world as an artist, show people my talent and skill, and help fund a young talented brother with artistic skill and creative vision.


PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD ABOUT MY CAMPAIGN AND MY ART!! THANK YOU ALL FOR YOUR WONDERFUL CONTRIBUTIONS. NO MATTER HOW SMALL OR LARGE, IT ALL MAKES A POSITIVE DIFFERENCE IN HELPING ME ATTEND THE SCHOOL OF THE ART INSTITUTE OF CHICAGO!  GOD BLESS YOU, TRULY.

story:
My name is Navdeep Toor. I want to raise money for underprivileged students at Hathur Primary School in India. Your donation will allow me to buy computers and uniforms.

In January 2014, I had the opportunity to travel to a local public school in India.  This school was in need of a water system, which would allow children to have access to clean and safe drinking water. The school did not have any funding from the government to support such an initiative and the parents of these students were not able to donate money since they were struggling to make ends meet themselves. When my family heard they needed clean drinking water, we headed down to the school.  The school is also very dear to my heart since my father went to school here as a child and my grandmother taught here as well.  The school was filled with the welcoming smiles of 275 students who were eager to meet us. This school had 5 classrooms which taught children from kindergarten to grade 5. Through the time I spent at the school and with the students, I noticed that this all-boys school did not have the same equipment and supplies as Canadian schools.. There weren’t any projectors, computers, or even round tables to work on. Each classroom consisted of single student desks set out in rows, and a chalkboard where the teacher would conduct her lessons.  I realized at this moment I wanted to donate more than just money for a clean water supply.  I made a promise to the children that when I came back next year I would visit them again. 

I will be traveling to India in March 2015. I would like to provide at least three computers for the school which will allow the students to learn basic computer skills . In addition, I would like to provide each student with a new school uniform. I understand that given our circumstances, we as a first world nation take technology for granted. However, I know these children would be thrilled and eternally grateful if they were given access to a computer. 

I am hoping you will donate today to a great cause. Your donation will allow under-privileged children get the opportunity to receive a better education and give them access to new opportunities and experiences.  Feel free to donate any amount to this cause. Spread the word! I will put up pictures after my trip and you can see all the smiles your donations have created.

story:
Taking baby steps to reach the Zenith of Success

Alpha International School Ranchi, prides itself in realizing and exploring the potential of every child. Here the grades doesn't matter but the will to perform, here child is first taught to be a good person rather than a high scorer, here dream realization is far more important than clearing exams. The institution caters to the specific needs of the children of all community. The school is known for harmonizing students of all community (Hinduism, Islam, Christianity and others). But where the school is striving to provide quality education, school is in dire need of capital for the infrastructure needs. It get too chilly in winters and too hot in summers. It becomes difficult during rainy season when the ceiling and walls water.
We need your help to
  • Build a proper roofing and windows for ventilation.
  • Install new black and white boards.
  • We have a small place which we want to build into a full fledged playground.
One of the foreigners rightly said we have all the software but our hardware is weak. Our poor infrastructure makes it difficult to carry on the routine teaching and fun activities, Your generous support is very much required.
"Please note that it Is not necessary to have a credit or debit card you can pay by net-banking as well, The bank account details are given below"

Your support will enable us to
your support of $5 will help us to get 7 bricks to build the walls of the school.
Your support of $20 will enable us to get quality black board
Your support of $100 will help us to remove the weeds and wild grass and remodel the empty space for the play grounds.
Your Support of $ 500 will help us to ventilate the classroom with proper windows,
Your support of $1000 and above will enable us to build one class room for the students.

Please note that you can pay through visa, Master Card debit card to the account or you can pay by net banking to the account of the school which we will donate here and you can see by the increase in dollar numbers.

Minimum donation is $ 1=INR 65
Name-Alpha Education & Social Enhancement Society
School Account number=495420110000136
IFSC code-BKID0004954
Bank of India Tupudana Branch Ranchi

Risks & Challenges

If we fail to reach this funding goal we will not be able to provide seamless education to the budding fellows and nurture the good learning. Its crucial for an institute to provide the basic amenity of proper shelter to the students. So, request you to help us

Other Ways You Can Help

if you can not help us no problem, just spread the news ask your friends and relatives to help us.
story_txt:
Taking baby steps to reach the Zenith of Success
Alpha International School Ranchi, prides itself in realizing and exploring the potential of every child. Here the grades doesn't matter but the will to perform, here child is first taught to be a good person rather than a high scorer, here dream realization is far more important than clearing exams. The institution caters to the specific needs of the children of all community. The school is known for harmonizing students of all community (Hinduism, Islam, Christianity and others). But where the school is striving to provide quality education, school is in dire need of capital for the infrastructure needs. It get too chilly in winters and too hot in summers. It becomes difficult during rainy season when the ceiling and walls water. 
We need your help to


Build a proper roofing and windows for ventilation.
Install new black and white boards.
We have a small place which we want to build into a full fledged playground.

One of the foreigners rightly said we have all the software but our hardware is weak. Our poor infrastructure makes it difficult to carry on the routine teaching and fun activities, Your generous support is very much required."Please note that it Is not necessary to have a credit or debit card you can pay by net-banking as well, The bank account details are given below"


Your support will enable us to your support of $5 will help us to get 7 bricks to build the walls of the school.Your support of $20 will enable us to get quality black boardYour support of $100 will help us to remove the weeds and wild grass and remodel the empty space for the play grounds.Your Support of $ 500 will help us to ventilate the classroom with proper windows,Your support of $1000 and above will enable us to build one class room for the students.Please note that you can pay through visa, Master Card debit card to the account or you can pay by net banking to the account of the school which we will donate here and you can see by the increase in dollar numbers.Minimum donation is $ 1=INR 65Name-Alpha Education & Social Enhancement SocietySchool Account number=495420110000136IFSC code-BKID0004954Bank of India Tupudana Branch Ranchi
