story:
Short Summary

Prema Metta School is doing important work educating fifty children living in severe poverty just outside Bodh Gaya, India in Bihar province, (the poorest province in India). The school operates on a very limited budget which comes from private donations. Many of the children are undernourished and this impacts their health, how they feel, and their ability to learn.  A light breakfast is provided at the school, but lunch is only served on special occasions, about once a month. These children come from families that Mother Theresa would call "the poorest of the poor".  Their parents work as laborers or farmers, but cannot  earn enough to feed their families well.

I first visited the Prema Metta School five years ago in 2009. During September and October 2014, I volunteered at Prema Metta as a teacher and teacher-trainer and got to know the school and its students, teachers and director very well over a five week period.  The students love to come to school. In many cases their parents have only minimal formal education and the families know that education will equal opportunities in the future... if the children are able to stay in school.

It was heart wrenching to see one girl have only a small piece of bread for lunch, and to see many others eat nothing at all during the "lunch break" each day.  I left India in mid-October with a commitment to do all I can to begin a food program which will provide a full meal daily for each child who comes to the school. 

I am partnering with a couple friends of Prema Metta to set up a food program which will ensure that the children of Prema Metta will get a healthy meal at school each day. Feeding each child daily will cost .50 cents  (US) per meal. If you can only donate $5, please do that.. it will provide 10 meals. If you can donate more, please do  as it will take many of us working together, sharing what we can,  to make this program a reality. $25 will feed all fifty children for one day. $150 will feed them for a week (school meets 5 1/2 days a week, and we will provide meals Monday through Saturday). We need $11,000 to start and fund the meal program for the first year.

Ieda Dias from Brazil has worked closely with the school for the past three years and has helped raise needed funds for a variety of projects including building renovations and  a small playground.  She lives much of the year in Bodh Gaya and will help oversee  this project. You can follow progress at the school on her blog (link below). (Her blog is in Portugese but if you click on the British flag it will appear in English).

http://oquevivipelomundo.blogspot.com/

(You can friend Ieda on facebook to see frequent postings from her volunteer work at the school, her facebook name is Eidia Dias ). Eliana Yarian, a Brazilian living in the US  as an ESL educator, is another partner in this project who has visited the school and has helped support varied projects there over the past three years. Anup Kumar, a local man from the village where the school is located started Prema Metta  in 2004 and is the director. He will supervise the daily aspects of the meal program.

I will be helping raise awareness about this program and raising funds to support it. I can answer questions and serve as a liaison between donors and the school.  All of us working on this campaign are volunteers. What you donate will go directly to the school to set up and run a meal program to feed the children of Prema Metta.


What We Need & What Will Be Provided

$11,000 will provide funds to start a lunch program: buying gas canisters, cooking pots, dishes, paying a cook, and funding food purchases to fund six lunches a week for  the first year of the program for the 50 students at the school who range from 3-12 years old . 

Lunch will include, rice, lentils, a vegetable dish, and a piece of fruit and sometimes yogurt or nuts.

  • Currently many of the students do not get lunch at all and many children are undernourished
  • This daily meal will be the only full meal many of the children will consume each day

The Impact

Your contribution will help ensure that 50 students will get complete meal 6 days a week for a year. Once the program is started, we intend to keep it going with annual appeals.

  • Well nourished children learn better, stay healthier, and feel better
  •  Parents who know their children will get a full meal at school are less likely to withdraw them to work to support the family. Food will help kids in school longer.

Risks & Challenges

If we do not raise $11,000 to provide meals for a year within 60 days...we will start the food program in a more limited way. Perhaps we will only serve a few meals each week, or we will not provide fruit at each meal. It is our hope to be able to begin to serve lunch at the school in the early days of 2015, or sooner if the funding comes in quickly.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share the link about this project with your friends and family.
  • Consider making a donation to this project as a birthday or holiday gift for a loved one. We will gladly send a card (or other form of recognition) acknowledging the contribution.
  • Consider sponsoring a child at the school. The cost of educating each student is $20 a month. We can arrange letters and even a video message from "your student".  If you would like to be a sponsor please contact me at mboslun@gmail.com so we can make arrangements to match you with a student. The school is funded entirely by the generosity of donors from around the world.

story:
We've reached our initial goal but we still need your support!

What is SharePointalooza?

SharePointalooza is a premier 2 day SharePoint and Office 365 conference held in Branson, MO on September 18th and 19th at the world class Branson Landing. SharePointalooza offers technical workshops and sessions on everything SharePoint and Office 365 related including: Development, Administration, Branding, Search, Social, Architecture,  BI and End User.  In addition SharePointalooza is introducing a new exclusive Executive track this year so business decision makers can better understand and utilize their SharePoint and Office 365 environments. 

What makes SharePointalooza unique?

What sets SharePointalooza apart from other events is it's unique combination of talent, price, and location. While most multi-day conferences charge up to $2000 for the same content and speakers, registration for SharePointalooza starts at just $50.
How can we do that??? Simple, we don't make a dime. To put it bluntly, we try to lose as little money as possible. SharePointalooza is a non-profit event created to help bring world-class technology conferences to regions of the country that rarely have access to this type of information. The speakers are the experts in their fields including MVP's, MCM's, and Microsoft employees who freely give of their time to help make SharePointalooza a success!
We also have a great time doing it! 

We need your support to help close out funding for our event which is just weeks away! With your support we can continue to bring events like these to areas that previously do not get the chance to experience a premium technology conference at extremely affordable costs for the attendees. 

Did I mention SharePointalooza is a not-for-profit event? Every little bit counts, and any extra money received will be used to make the conference even better. 

It's going to be a great time and we hope you can make it out to Branson to see us!

Thanks for stopping by and thanks for your support!

To find out more about SharePointalooza visit http://www.sharepointalooza.org 

Why donate?

Bringing a technology conference to a smaller city is always a difficult chore. Sponsors are less likely to support these events because they typically do not have local offices in the area or they feel the attendance might not be large enough to justify the expense.

This is the FIFTH conference we've put together and by far the largest. We have a loyal group of attendees that appreciate this area of the country being served and with the help of this IndieGoGo project we can ensure that all are expenses are paid and it will make future events possible.

We actually need more than the stated goal, but the $1,500 will ensure some of the final necessities are covered.

story:
Who Are We?

Kenosha Unified School District, located in the southeast corner of Wisconsin, is home to an amazing theater arts program. My name is Jodi Williams and I am the Technical Director, and proud parent of a KUSD theater participant, for Bradford High School, one of six high schools that participate in our program. I have been at Bradford for fifteen years. For ten of those fifteen, we have undertaken this trip to the International Thespian Festival in Lincoln, NE.

Our school district is large, the third largest in Wisconsin, and our theater program is large and growing. Being a large district in an increasingly urban area means many of our schools are Title 1 and many of our students and their families cannot bridge the financial gap between the minimum education their students need and the opportunities that will help them grow, both as individuals and as post high school minded thinkers. The goal of this campaign is to fund the transportation to Lincoln for our company and help ease the overall cost for families. Last year, we pushed to raise $80,000.00 for the trip, the cost of taking our very large group to the 2015 festival. Through Indiegogo, we managed to bring in $4,000.00. This year, we want to pay for the entire bus!

When at the festival, students are exposed to college life, meet other performers from across the country, compete for scholarships (regardless of career path), talk to college recruiters, see shows, participate in workshops and make connections that last a life time. I have watched my students get excited about education, discover their own hidden talents, over come fears and come home eager to be better, work harder and create more. It is an invaluable experience.

What We Need & What You Get

The bus cost is $11,500.00. That gets our students to and from Lincoln. Once on campus, its a walking adventure. We want to share our gratitude by including our donors in the program, sending them pictures from the trip and t-shirts so they can show their support to all. If any far sighted company wants to pay for our bus, we will find a way to show our support all the way from Kenosha to Lincoln and back. If we only reach part of our goal, all the funds will still go toward the bus and we will help pull the cost per student down, if only a little.

The Impact

Every little bit counts. We will nickel and dime our way there if need be. We have managed to get the entire company there, every year we've entered, and we don't intend to leave anyone behind this year. The educational value, the personal value, and the rewards for students is too great. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know money is tight for everyone, so if you can't give to our campaign, share our cause. If you're alumni, pass the message on. Share and share and share, and kick in a dollar or two. We will get them there.

Once on campus, its a walking adventure. We want to share our gratitude by including our donors in the program, sending them pictures from the trip and t-shirts so they can show their support to all. If any far sighted company wants to pay for our bus, we will find a way to show our support all the way from Kenosha to Lincoln and back. If we only reach part of our goal, all the funds will still go toward the bus and we will help pull the cost per student down, if only a little.   The Impact
Every little bit counts. We will nickel and dime our way there if need be. We have managed to get the entire company there, every year we've entered, and we don't intend to leave anyone behind this year. The educational value, the personal value, and the rewards for students is too great. 

    Other Ways You Can Help We know money is tight for everyone, so if you can't give to our campaign, share our cause. If you're alumni, pass the message on. Share and share and share, and kick in a dollar or two. We will get them there.

story:
I’m most excited to take this training because it’s all about the body. So much of what I know already is what to do when you’re already ill or hurt but yoga, in a sense, is a preventive practice. I’ll be learning more about the human body and how to keep it functioning at its best. I have benefitted from a personal yoga practice for three years and I know how it will help me maintain my own physical, spiritual, and mental health while I go through the stress of the next several years.

This budget would allow me to complete the 200-hour basic training to become a Registered Yoga Teacher through Yoga Alliance, which would allow me to teach three different kinds of yoga: Restorative, Yin and Vinyasa. The coursework also includes Intuitive and Authenticity Training and Personal Yogic Training.

I appreciate you taking the time to read my story. Please consider making a donation to help make it possible for me to have this adventure.


Thank you for your consideration!Lakeisha

story:
We just found out that indiegogo is actually taking 9% of our dollars raised!  If you are going to donate, PLEASE visit our site www.nourishingyogis.org and donate through that button, or come to our fundraiser to pay in cash or check. Thanks for understanding!

Many blessings,

Gina


For the last several years, our lives have settled into a nice, comfortable routine.  Gina is  home schooling mom, keeping the house and raising the children the best she can, with all those little details that a Mama strives to offer her little ones.  Stephen is an involved dad and supportive husband, he offers his services on sundays to our Church as a multi-faceted musician and has taken on the role as a 9-5 carpenter to support the family.  We live in our modest home, with a small but wonderful yard, three young children and our two aging pups.  


Our dream for many years has been to open a center of some sort.  The vision has changed through the years and is often pushed to the far reaches of our consciousness, but it has always remained a strong desire for our family.  The dream is one which allows our family to be our truest selves.  In this dream, we are rooted deep into our foundation, yet stretching our furthest limbs to share our talents, to teach and inspire those around us to follow their deepest passions. 


Six months ago we had a small glimpse into an awakening.  We knew that it was time to take action and make some changes in our lives.  It was time to uproot from the comfortable, un-comfort of our suburban dwelling, from our roles as carpenter and housewife.  Immediately the synchronicities began to happen.  That small awakening began to grow.  Through countless hours of prayer and meditation, our path is becoming so clear.  Opportunities continue to arise in which we are able to push our comfort level, test our abilities.   We were able collaborate with a local yoga studio.  Stephen was able to take part in a Yoga Teacher Training, a long time dream of his.  In exchange, we provided raw, organic, vegan spreads for the group.   This challenge Gina was excited to take on, as much of her peace lies in food preparation and serving others delicious, healthy food.  


God has provide us with the faith to surrender into the flow that is all around us.  And what has been presented is an educational journey of sorts.  We are going to school, without enrolling in a University.  We are packing up only the essentials and hitting the road.  Our plan?  Well that’s a mystery even to us.  We are contacting retreat centers of all shapes and sizes, throughout the country in hopes to exchange work for a glimpse into what they are doing.  We will learn from them in ways that we may never expect.  Our first major destination?  The Tree of Life Rejuvenation Center in Patagonia, Az.  Here awaits an experience working in THE live food cafe.  The Tree of Life Center is a Live Food, Spiritual Community best known for its work with diabetic patients.  They have 21 day programs that get a high percentage of the diabetics off of insulin.  Along with the nutritional wonders of the community, it is a strong spiritual community, practicing yoga, meditation, bhakti, seva and so much more. The length of our stay here is still undetermined.  We will stay at least two weeks, but that all depends on how the stars line up.  The rest of our journey will be in faith.  Whether we remain there or continue pursuing other centers, our intention will remain the same, to absorb all of the knowledge and growth that we can. We will take all of the bits and pieces that we have learned and translate them to our own vision.  Eventually we will settle in and manifest a place of healing, growing, Spirit, and of course, nutrition.


So, it is time for us to raise some funds.  Why are we raising funds?  Well, we can’t do this on our own. Through prayer and meditation, we were inspired to have a FUN-raiser.  An evening of yoga for all ages, live food, dancing, silent auctions, raffles, magical moments and music, music, music!  We’re giving it our heart and soul, blood, sweat and tears, to make this night a great one for everybody.  

When is this event that you don’t want to miss??  Saturday, October 16th, 7:00.

Where will you find us?? Amy at the Mystic Yoga Shala has been gracious to let us use the yoga studio.

How much is this night of magic and fun??? The donation includes organic, vegan, live food  dinner and dessert, singer/songwriter performances, African Drummers, a Kirtan led by our own, Stephen Law, raffles and more.  We’d prefer to work on a sliding scale, with a suggested donation of $25 minimum.  Want to pass on dinner?  join us at 8:00 for dessert, Drumming, and the Kirtan for $15.


This is important!  If you are planning on coming, please RSVP we want to be sure to have enough food for everyone! 

RSVP bliss@nourishingyogis.org


How can you save your spot?? Make your chosen donation here!  Be sure to specify that you are coming and how many, including yourself, you are paying for.  


If you can’t make the party, but love what we are doing and just want to contribute to good vibrations and raising consciousness, we are so grateful for any and every blessing that comes our way. 



The time is now for every one of us to follow our passion, Are you following yours?  What are you waiting for?


questions?  email us at bliss@nourishingyogis.org 


We Need Your Help!  Pass on our story to your family and friends, send them our way, invite them to join in the fun, or to simply help us reach our goal.  


10% of the proceeds will shared with a Mexican Orphanage adopted by the Tree of Life Rejuvenation Center.

The time is now for every one of us to follow our passion, Are you following yours?  What are you waiting for?

questions?  email us at bliss@nourishingyogis.org 

We Need Your Help!  Pass on our story to your family and friends, send them our way, invite them to join in the fun, or to simply help us reach our goal.  10% of the proceeds will shared with a Mexican Orphanage adopted by the Tree of Life Rejuvenation Center.

story:
Hey my name is Angela Latimer and I recently just got accepted into one of the most prestigious Master’s program for video editing. Let me explain to you how much of a huge deal this is for me, AFI Conservatory  better known as American Film Institute Conservatory  only accept  14 editors each year for their program and out of thousands of US and International students that apply, I am one of the blessed  14 students chosen for this program. Yes me, a shy little black girl from a family of 10 children gets an opportunity of a life time. I have to say that I am lost for words because I’ve been editing for 6 years now with most of my knowledge being self-taught, and I feel as if my hard work is finally paying off.

 Upon being accepted I also have a tuition deposit and an additional class to take before I can even start school. All of this is a process to hold my spot. I need to raise $2000 overall, but most importantly I need to raise $1,000 by May 13th of 2011 to hold my spot for school. If I don’t raise this money all my hard work would have been for nothing. I’m working as many hours as they will allow me at work, I’m freelancing as well, I am doing everything I can to raise money. I know the economy is rough so give what you can and if you can’t, then send someone who can in my direction.

 You guys this is my dream,  since I was a kid I knew I wanted to do something in the movie industry and a lot of people told me I was way too quiet, well I guess  there’s a reason for everything because having patience along with being quiet brought my editing skills a very long way.  I want to edit movies, commercials, and documentaries and I’m only $2000 away help me knock this barrier down one edit at a time.

story:
Short Summary

Our group is made up of three service-oriented artists studying at the University of Melbourne. Many organizations have rightly dedicated time and energy towards the academic education of disadvantaged global communities; however, artistic expression is often neglected.

We have received partial funding from our university for carrying out an arts-service project in East Timor whereby breakdancing, digital music production and photographic documentation skills will be taught to the youth of a rural community as an inexpensive and positive creative arts engagement.

  • JJ Richardson - Breakdancing will be taught as a physical means of creative expression suitable for rural and urban communities since it can be practiced on any ground without requiring specialised equipment.
  • Bryan Philips - Music production will be taught as a creative outlet to further cultural identity, and bring it onto the world stage through the medium of hip-hop music. With the means of a portable digital studio, participants will be enabled to produce and perform their own music. At the end of the two weeks the system will be donated to the community.
  • Chris Parkinson - Photography and documentation skills will be taught as a means to capture and preserve the creative and cultural identity of the Timorese people, creating important cultural transmission opportunities for the stories to be shared internationally.

The two week long project will be documented by the young participants and will culminate in a performance choreographed by those learning breakdancing and performed to the songs created in the mobile studio. This project will act as a self-contained community interaction project that will empower the Timorese youth into pursuing personal and cultural expression after the project's completion.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Although we have recieved partial funding from the University of Melbourne that covers airfare and vaccination, we still need:

  • $1000 for a mobile music studio, including an ipad, microphone, amplifier, headphones, and all the necessary connectors. (This will be donated to the community at the end of the project.)
  • $1800 for room and board (rather expensive in East Timor), and food (rather cheap) for all three of us.
  • $1300 to reimburse Arte Moris for allowing us to use their facilities,  facilitators and translators.
  • $400 for transportation in East Timor. (Most likely a car will be rented, because the motor bikes are rather unsafe, and taxis can be more costly/less reliable.)

If we don't reach our goal, we will still put the money towards these ends, although the trip may have to be shorter or the portable music studio less equipped.

Richmond Rotary is also supporting our project, so please support them http://www.rotaryrichmond.org.au/

 

The Impact

Hip-hop benefits developing countries because it provides young people with free creative outlets that can be developed independently or in a group. It bridges traditional linguistic and cultural gaps, encourages cultural consumption and promotes the sharing of knowledge on an international level. These artistic outlets can act as a cultural and creative voice for frustration, encouraging non-violent competition, a vessel for preserving tradition or an easel on which to paint contemporary culture.

Hip-hop is practiced in almost every country worldwide and allows isolated groups to join the international community.  The style is mainly characterised by breakdancing, hip-hop music and graffiti. Asia is developing into a powerhouse on the international hip-hop arena, however East Timor has no real scene regarding music or dance, though it does have a rich history of graffiti. Although major East Timorese cities have access to international youth trends, rural communities are more isolated, lying at the margins of cultural and economic disadvantage. In this context rural youth are at risk of disengagement from current nation building processes unless offered positive alternatives.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t help out with a donation, we still love you. Just don't forget to tell your friends about us. Also, down the road try to support initiatives dedicated to making East Timor a better country for its citizens. Support the arts, and support indiegogo supporting the arts.

 

Links Relating to the Project

http://peaceofwall.blogspot.com.au/ Chris Parkinson's blog of East Timor. With pictures from his book.

http://vimeo.com/27683451   An interview with Chris Parkinson.

story:
Despite progress in recent years, girls continue to suffer severe disadvantage and exclusion in education systems throughout their lives.Girls’ education is both an intrinsic right and a critical lever to reaching other development objectives. Providing girls with an education helps break the cycle of poverty: educated women are less likely to marry early and against their will; less likely to die in childbirth; more likely to have healthy babies; and are more likely to send their children to school.

This month we are supporting children in Haiti to have an education… go to our donor page and pick a child to sponsor for year - … it’s only 35 cents a day …$125 / year. 

Supporters like you are critical to providing girls with an education and new opportunities. 

Let’s get involved to help the next generation build a better world.


PS:

Your donation is tax deductible whether online or by check:

check can be made to:

Community Mission for Hope

Po Box 12195 Naples, Fl 34101 - USA

story:
Earlier this year my Daughter Stefanie Edwards was selected by (her Employer) The Body Shop to represent the region at their Children On The Edge (COTE) play scheme in East Timor.

On the 1st of September Stefanie will be travelling to East Timor for a 10 day volunteer programme, during this time she will be working in the community centre, a safe haven and refuge for some of the worlds poorest and most vulnerable children.

The COTE centre supplies vital health care, hygiene and education for the community as well as providing a child friendly space for the children to play and learn. These basic human rights are something that we often take for granted in our community.

In order to participate in the COTE program she must raise $2000 to help purchase medication, clothing, art and craft supplies for activities during my stay. To help her with my fundraising efforts she is appealing to family, friends and the generosity of the community to support her in raising these valuable funds.

Any donations, large or small will be gratefully accepted and are sure to make a real difference in the lives of these beautiful children.

Please feel free to share this with friends and family and if possible please ask your work places if they would like to make a donation.

Children on the Edge is a registered charity 1101441

NOTE: Donations to a Child friendly space in East Timor are NOT tax deductible.

Thank you all for you support :)))

story:
The Challenge?

Each spring, thousands of talented and well trained music students emerge from well-respected universities passionate about performing for us and educating our kids. Sadly, they discover there are far more qualified musicians than jobs in our current economy.  Even harder, many have never been taught the skills, resources, and industry knowledge required for them to live their dreams.  If they donâ€™t learn the entrepreneurial attitudes and skills they need to create professional success, their gifts will go to waste.


 The Opportunity

The Road of Creativityâ€™s Music Entrepreneurship Retreat, a five-day immersion experience, was founded by renown saxophonist and professor Connie Frigo and designed to equip both emerging and professional musicians with the tools they need to keep great music alive and well in the US.   Participants will learn to build financially sustainable, fulfilling careers by learning from and networking with nationally recognized artists, educators, industry experts and business advisors from the Road of Creativity, Dâ€™Addario and the University of South Carolina.  They will learn skills for: 

 

  • Online marketing and personal branding
  • Funding
  • Entrepreneurship and leadership
  • Engaging Communities
  • Networking and building audiences
  • Writing for professional success
  • Defining goals and self-examination


How You Can Help

If you agree that our communities need the connectivity music affords and that musicians deserve a strong opportunity to put all their years of studying, practicing, lesson planning and donating performances to greater use; if you want to help them define and contribute the unique value they can bring forward; if you want to help them gain the tools they need to create opportunities that don't otherwise exist, please contribute. With your help, we will raise $15,000 for a scholarship fund that will reduce the cost of tuition for 75 highly qualified musicians who can only attend if we help them.


Letâ€™s support musicians to bring their gifts into the world.  Music brings people together and cliche as it sounds, it knows no boundaries. Your assistance will help musicians to learn the fundamentals of music entrepreneurship and launch productive and meaningful careers.

create opportunities that don't otherwise exist, please contribute. With your help, we will raise $15,000 for a
scholarship fund that will reduce the cost of tuition for 75 highly qualified
musicians who can only attend if we help them. 
Letâ€™s support musicians to bring their gifts into the
world.  Music brings people together and cliche  as it sounds, it knows no
boundaries. Your assistance will help musicians to learn the fundamentals of
music entrepreneurship and launch productive and meaningful careers.

story:
If you haven't heard yet, Colorado is burning up. Literally. There have been a bunch of fires to kick off the summer and one recently started just west of Colorado Springs in Waldo Canyon. It has already affected thousands of people and seeing how it is zero percent contained, I assume the damage is only going to grow.

A group of friends and I want to help out in some way and made this fundraiser in an effort to do so. We want to go to the shelters and help the families out by bringing them clothing, food, toys for kids, food for animals, or even a Chipotle burrito would put a smile on their face. Really we want to do anything that can help. 

Here are some links so you can check out the fire nd its impact thus far:

http://www.dailycamera.com/news/ci_20929068/waldo-canyon-fire-evacuation-manitou-springs

 

http://www.kktv.com/news/headlines/Fire_Reported_In_Waldo_Canyon_160124015.html

 

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6ri1qkZSJbU&feature=related

 

Any donation would, and will, help or if you have ideas of other ways to help out send me a message or post a comment.

story:
Our bench banner graphics are instructive, precise, and have contact numbers as well as simple instructions about how to help, and how to get help.

Suicidal thinking is extremely common, but is usually kept hidden because of shame. It is nothing to be ashamed of!

We need to START TALKING about how to combat suicidal thinking, and KEEP NO MORE SECRETS. By contributing to this project, you WILL definitely help SAVE LIVES.

To make this project work, we band together as a consortium of individuals, non-profits, and agencies in order to GIVE A SHOUT OUT TO PEOPLE that SUICIDAL THINKING is NOT A PERSONALITY DEFECT!

We need $10,800 to buy six rotating bus bench ads in our county for one whole year.

This campaign's motto is "!!NO MORE SECRETS!!" which is printed on all of our perks.

 If we don't raise the whole amount, we will buy as many bench ads as we can. Then we will spend the rest on event banners to use around the county at fairs, exhibits, town hall meetings, and anywhere else people gather.

OPEN PUBLIC CONVERSATION about ALL public health issues destroys stigma where it starts: in SECRET. 

Suicidal thinking strikes 1 in 5 people at some point in our lives. It is common and must be talked about. That's the only proven way to stop it.

Look CLOSELY at these FACES. Every face is overlaid by hundreds of other faces. They are our friends, parents, children, siblings, love's of our live's... ALL of these are faces of people we have loved and lost to the stigma and secrecy of suicidal thinking.

Mesa County Colorado suffers a suicide rate that is 3X the USA national average. Suicide is the 2nd leading cause of death for those between the ages of 10 and 34.

If you have lost someone you care about to suicide, we are so very sorry for your loss

This campaign is a cooperative effort between KRC4LIFE, Putting a Face on Suicide, NAMI Western Slope, Western Colorado Suicide Prevention Foundation, the QPR institute, and Colorado West Regional Mental Health.

Don't have any cash righ now?

Hey, no worries. Just please please please share this campaign. 

You can STOMP the STIGMA monster by giving a shout out for us.  

Peace and love to EVERYONE. 

 

If you want to talk about your own, or someone else's, suicidal thinking,  please call 800-273-TALK

 

*Western Colorado Suicide Prevention Foundation 501(c)3 is managing the funds raised by this campaign.

*Your contribution is tax deductible.

story:
My name is Julian Hunt and I am 10 years old. I live in Kirkland WA and I love using technology. My favorite computer game is Minecraft. I want to go to Alaska because I did a school project on it and ever since it's been a dream of mine.

I got an invitation from People to People student ambassador program saying they invited me to go to Alaska for 18 days during the summer of 2013. I was accepted into the program and now a student ambassador.  I will need to raise funds for the trip.

Some of things I will get to experience include going to Denali National Park, exploring glaciers and wildlife, and learning to cook and live with the locals.

This trip will go towards high school credits and will also be very important on my college applications.

I need a total of $4500 for my trip. I decided to raise a portion of the funds on this website. If I do not reach my entire funding goal here, i will use the funds raised towards my overall goal.

I am also raising funds with a recycling program for cell phones.

I AM OPENING MY EYES.

I AM BUILDING MY FUTURE

I AM PLANTING SEEDS OF HOPE.

Please pass the word out to friends and other family members that you think might be able to help. 

 

Thank you so much for all of your support.  I am very excited for my trip and to be a part of this.

 

Julian Hunt

story:
My name is Paula and I have dreamed of becoming a life coach for quite a few years now. I strongly feel that now is the time, but I need your help to make it happen. As a single mother, I’m used to doing things myself. Whether it’s chopping down our own Christmas tree, teaching my 16 year-old how to drive, putting myself through massage therapy school, or unclogging a blocked toilet, it’s been very important to me to show both my girls that we, as women, can do anything. That’s why asking for help is kind of hard for me; in the past, I have thought of it as a sign of weakness. But I read something recently that really hit home for me: Vulnerable is the new strong. If I’ve been told once I’ve been told a million times how strong I am. Having been through the loss of both parents, my brother, a sister, and my home, all within a 5 year period, I know I’m not only strong, I’m freaking Wonder Woman. Being vulnerable is different, though. It’s baring your soul, telling people your dreams, knowing they can shoot you down with the most off-the-cuff comments: "Why can't you just get a regular 9-5 job, like everybody else?", or “Are you sure that’s a good idea?”, or worse “Who are YOU to coach anyone? What’s so great about your life that you think you can tell anyone else how to live theirs?”. Well, the fact is, no coach's life is perfect. Just like some doctors have high cholesterol and some therapists have daddy issues, we're all just learning as we go. So, as the saying goes, I‘m going to “feel the fear and do it anyway“. I’ve spent the last 16 years putting my own agenda to the side so that I could focus on raising my kids & afford them with everything they need, & happily so, but now that my younger daughter has started high school, I can see a time in the not too distant future when I can focus on my next goal as a healer: Certified Life Coach. The only thing holding me back is the tuition.

I first discovered the QSCA (Quantum Success Coaching Academy) about 4 years ago, while browsing the internet looking for some training that would enhance my abilities as a healer. I’ve been a massage therapist since 2006, and I love the work I do, but I want to do more. One of my greatest joys is helping people feel better, so it seemed like a natural segue way to enter the coaching arena. I’ve spoken with several students & graduates of the QSCA (and even took advantage of a few free coaching sessions!), and they have all spoken glowingly of their experience there. I’ve also spoken to a few of my closest friends and advisors to ask their frank opinions on me becoming a coach, and they have every confidence that this is a great fit for me. My experiences as a massage therapist have already led me to do some coaching, whether it’s doing a guided visualization at the end of a session, or helping a client who was trying to get pregnant by giving her some Law of Attraction tips. All of us have coached friends, whether we know it or not, just by listening, giving advice, etc., but with a certification I could make a living from it! The QSCA is fully accredited by the ICF (International Coaching Federation), and included in this program is all it takes to start your own practice, including business building and marketing strategies. I am not undertaking this venture lightly, or on a whim, I have done my research to find a reputable program-I am on a mission to make a difference, and you can make a difference by helping me! The tuition is $5,000 for the year-long program, and it includes all the materials needed to become certified.

I first heard about www.indiegogo.com when the video of the school bus monitor who was tormented terribly by those young boys on her school bus was shown on the news. Someone decided to raise money for her on indiegogo.com to send her on a dream vacation, and they raised over $600,000! It occurred to me then that people really DO want to help, people are truly kind, & willing to help lift others up. Despite some tragedy and loss in my life, I am truly intent on building a better life for myself and my girls, and with your kindness and support, I will achieve this goal!

If you simply cannot afford to help financially, it’s OK! I’ve been there. But you can still help by spreading the word to your network of friends and family. Maybe you or your spouse work for a big corporation that does charitable work. Maybe your church group would like to support my cause. You never know the impact that your positive intentions can have! If you’ve read this far, thank you for your time. If you feel  like you want to move forward and make a huge impact on the lives of  not only me and my daughters, but all my future clients, thank you, thank you, and THANK YOU!!

story:
Our Story

 

IMAC is a nonprofit that works withstudents in the Superintendent's Leadership Program in Montgomery County, Maryland to provide career and leadership training, service learning opportunities, and life skills.  To teach students about making an impact and provide required service learning hours for graduation, we coordinate activities that allow students to design, execute and evaluate long term projects that make impact on the underserved and most vulnerable.  Students have identified projects in tutoring, drug prevention mentoring, college mentoring, the disabled and the homeless.  For three years, the students have built on previous work to help the hungry and the homeless in our county.  There are more than 400 homeless children and more than 1250 homeless adults in our county.  The students canvas for nonperishable food to provide to shelters and food pantries; they adopt low income families and try to provide a basket of food each month along with a warm dinner; they raise money to make bag lunches for homeless shelters, and conduct awareness walks throughout the county.  They are learning how to conduct outreach through social networking and local media, as well as learning to write original articles and opinion articles to submit to the media.  IMAC teaches students, some of whom are low income or homeless, how to conduct process and outcome evaluations so that they can continually improve their work.  Over the past three years, we now have developed a model that is sustainable and allows new students to join at any time. 

The Impact

(What is the impact your campaign may have on others? What if your campaign doesn't happen, what are the consequences? Make it real for people.)

Our model is proven to make impact on the students we serve and in turn the individuals they serve.  We help students learn to transform lives by creating sustainable programs to address pressing social issues, like hunger and homelessness.  Through our training, students are able to gain experience and skills that carry over into the workplace, thereby increasing their workforce skills.  We also ensure that students graduate from high school by providing required service learning hours that hold some back from graduating.  Peer interaction and our college information, demonstrates to all students the importance of lifelong learning. 

The students currently working with us are coordinating a major festival that will include a pledge and mini-walk for the hungry and homeless children, packing tote bags with meals for hungry children, collecting healthy snacks for homeless children,  chef demonstration, and motivational speakers.  All walkers and visitors are being asked to donate at least $5 and 200 people are targeted.  All proceeds will go to a local children's program.  The students would like to reach a goal of $2000.  Your donation can help us get there. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need a minimum of $2000

$1000 will go directly to a local childrens poverty charity

$500 in grocery store and gift cards will be purchased for low income families

We have approximately $2000 already that is being used to buy monthly food baskets for adopted families and to buy the necessary items to make 100 bagged lunches for area shelters (sandwich, beverage, fruit, crackers).  The students use their own money and fundraising to purchase gifts for homeless and low income children.  We were able to work with Mattel Toys to get more than 400 toys that were donated to children in area shelters. 

If we don't meet the $2000 goal, we will provide as many meals and gift cards as we can buy.  But we will move forward with our project, because it will raise awareness and pledges from more students and citizens to participate in this effort next year. 

Give today and get your name included on our materials for the festival and we might even send you a t-shirt after the event!! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this site with your friends and family. 

Like us on Facebook at http://www.facebook.com/#!/groups/236642139728447/

Help us help others today.

story:
Project Objective

 

The project objective is to build a library in the summer of 2012 at the Guanin Community Center, la Piedra, municipality Guerra, Province Santo Domingo. 45 minutes drive from Santo Domingo Capital. This Center was started with the aim of educating destitute children who would otherwise not have had an education. The Guanin Center,Inc., provides a safe and supportive environment where youth from resource poor communities (mostly in communities where poor Dominican-Haitians live) can experience new opportunities, help others who are even more needy, overcome barriers, build positive relationships, and develop confidence and skills.

 

We want to build this library this summer with the children and volunteers for the summer camp. Last year we built a swimming pool with the summer camp volunteers and kids. This summer the library will be our project. Please come join us, and helping build this library. During this time period, we will also be keeping a blog for you to follow with nightly journals, pictures, and videos of our progress.

 

With your help, we hope to reach our goal of $10,000.

 

The Inspiration

 

The inspiration for the project is to give an education to children that would have otherwise not had one. Most of the Haitian kids who are born in the Dominican Republic without birth certificate, cannot assist to the public school.

 

The people of these communities live by raising chickens and a little food, but not even enough for local consumption, and by doing occasional work for hire. 60% of them are Haitian descent. They live in extreme poverty. About 60% earn less than US$2 per day, and one in three earns less than US$1 per day.

 

They live with no running water and electricity; there are no telephone lines, no Internet or other types of technology available. The closest first aid center is a 45-minute drive away. The closest school, which only has grades Pre-K through 4, is 40 minutes walking distance. Some are ravaged by HIV Aids, and live in semi-permanent shanties. The environment in la Piedra young people's dreams and aspirations, which would be realized in most other places in the world with a little hard work and determination. Most children in la Piedra are not even aware of the possibility that they can become anything more than slum dwellers, petty thieves, prostitutes or gardeners for the nearby mansion or work only the construction industry, because they will never get Dominican birth certificate. We want to change this predicament and give them an opportunity through education - the only leveler in society. With an education opportunities to succeed can be made possible. “Education is a companion which no future can depress, no crime can destroy, no enemy can alienate it and no nepotism can enslave.”

 

Promoting Stability in the Guanin Community Center

 

The school tackles the following three issues to promote stability:

 

1) Ethnic Conflict: La Piedra has 100 people, 60% Haitian descent. Was founded to incorporate people from all different backgrounds. Some of the oldest residents here remember life in La Piedra (its name, appropriately, translates as "The Rock") in the 1940s, around 70 years ago, when all the nearby Ingenio San Luis sugar lands and the undeveloped lands around them were a small part of the vast estates of "El Presidente" Rafael Leónidas Trujillo, the fierce dictator who ruled the Dominican Republic from 1930-1961. After Trujillo´s assassination in May of 1961, the Dominican government laid claim to all the surrounding land and promptly sold thousands of square meters of it to an international or U.S. This library is able to attract youths from many different quarters.

 

2) Gender disparities: La Piedra is in dire need of community-building projects. Having realized that women are the change-makers in low-income communities, The Guanin Community Center has placed a strong emphasis on recruiting and catering to women. Currently the student body is comprised 60% of women. The school has a boarding-house for its girls, who live in la Piedra under the daily risk of gender violence and sexual assaults either en route to their homes, after school or in their homes themselves.

 

3) Vocational Training: Students must be given an education that goes beyond humanities and the liberal arts and sciences. The main reason for the high rate of high school dropouts is their inability to financially support themselves as full-time students. They need to be able to learn trades with which to support their immediate needs. To this end, the curriculum was constructed to include vocational skills and allow students to meet short-term demands. The skills include: farming, small-engine repair, simple architecture, micro-finance, carpentry, brick construction skills, animal husbandry and etc.

 

Project's Impact

 

Project Implementation: Guanin Community Center Library at la Piedra

 

As part of a global social entrepreneurship initiative designed to create highly motivating, low cost ways to improve educational opportunities in the developing world, we will orchestrate the building of ‘Guanin Community Center Library’ in the summer of 2012 (June 22) to supplement the education.

 

(1) Economy Boosting

 

 

 

Labor: For the specialized jobs such as welding and electric wiring we will hire a team from Santo Domingo Capital. We will provide jobs for the community members and all our volunteers for the Summer Camp, that do not require technical skill to help build the library, including: painting, excavation, and heavy lifting. This will offer many of the students a head-start on their future vocational training with some first-hand experience. Their involvement will also aid in fostering a sense of ownership. Furniture and Fixtures: We will purchase doors, window frames, windows, desks and chairs from the local industrial area that produces the low-cost material.

 

(2) Community Building and Long-Term Sustainability

 

Murals: We will organize community activities that don’t require specialized labor (i.e., artwork). Murals will illustrate our tradition, getting the community as involved as possible and providing students with a sense of ownership. Our paid labor will construct the building; the students will add the personal touch, turning it into a library that they can take pride in.

 

Books: The children of la Piedra currently have access to very few used books, most of which the kids have read a few times over. To help further their education, we will be supplying the library with over one thousand textbooks to cater for our three goals:

 

a) One, helping the Dominican-Haitian community to read and write.

 

b) Two, literacy program for youths and adults Certificate of Secondary Education.

 

c) Three, promoting gender equality as women have proven to be strong agents of community-building. We will buy and get these books from the Dominican Ministry of Education. On top of the curriculum books that the students will use, we will get computer and internet service. More books were specifically picked to provide the students with income-generating basic skills (e.g., farming, small engine repair, simple architecture, micro-finance, carpentry, brick laying, and animal husbandry). We concentrate on these income-generating skills because they provide short-term benefits that alleviate the abject poverty in the DR leading to lower dropout rates and keeping students in school for the long run.

 

(3) Cost-Effective Materials in line with the Governing By-Laws of the Dominican Republic County Council

 

Shipping Containers: We will be using shipping containers because; we can receive books, computers and school supply free tax. Guanin Center, Inc. is a non-profit Dominican organization and we are also registered as a non-profit, charitable organization in the USA under the IRS (501c3).

 

Through the joint effort from the library and school, the students will not just engage in academics, but also vocational training. Involvement in carpentry, tailor work and small-scale farming, English and etc., can bring short-term returns to keep students motivated and long-term benefits to education. Education is fundamental for helping to break the perpetual poverty cycle in the Dominican Republic and Haiti. Through the youth, this knowledge will spread through the close-knit shanty-towns. The Guanin Community Center Library is an ethnic and community building enterprises that will create a space where young minds can be molded to realize that there are more similarities between the two genders and the different ethnic groups than there are differences.

 

What We Need

 

The expenses of building the library and filling it with books will require $10,000. We realize this is a hefty sum of money, but we are all extremely dedicated to reaching our goal. Due to the small size of the group, each member must work as hard as possible to procure as much money as possible to make this project happen.

 

We are raising funds in three phases:

 

a) First, procuring funds to fix and building structure to build one side in block and segment, the old truck the first Dominican Lady donated to us 1 year ago;

 

b) Second, fund-raising for the furniture to be used in the library;

 

c) Third, procuring funds for buying books and purchasing shipping containers of school supply.

 

Every donation, regardless of size will truly help make a difference! We ask you to kindly consider this and please help support our mission! Each and every one of us knows that without your kind help, and many others', this could not happen. Thank you so incredibly much.

 

The Team

 

Guanin Center volunteers.

 

www.guanin.org
story_txt:
Project Objective
 
The project objective is to build a library in the summer of 2012 at the Guanin Community Center, la Piedra, municipality Guerra, Province Santo Domingo. 45 minutes drive from Santo Domingo Capital. This Center was started with the aim of educating destitute children who would otherwise not have had an education. The Guanin Center,Inc., provides a safe and supportive environment where youth from resource poor communities (mostly in communities where poor Dominican-Haitians live) can experience new opportunities, help others who are even more needy, overcome barriers, build positive relationships, and develop confidence and skills.
 
We want to build this library this summer with the children and volunteers for the summer camp. Last year we built a swimming pool with the summer camp volunteers and kids. This summer the library will be our project. Please come join us, and helping build this library. During this time period, we will also be keeping a blog for you to follow with nightly journals, pictures, and videos of our progress.
 
With your help, we hope to reach our goal of $10,000.
 
The Inspiration
 
The inspiration for the project is to give an education to children that would have otherwise not had one. Most of the Haitian kids who are born in the Dominican Republic without birth certificate, cannot assist to the public school.
 
The people of these communities live by raising chickens and a little food, but not even enough for local consumption, and by doing occasional work for hire. 60% of them are Haitian descent. They live in extreme poverty. About 60% earn less than US$2 per day, and one in three earns less than US$1 per day.
 
They live with no running water and electricity; there are no telephone lines, no Internet or other types of technology available. The closest first aid center is a 45-minute drive away. The closest school, which only has grades Pre-K through 4, is 40 minutes walking distance. Some are ravaged by HIV Aids, and live in semi-permanent shanties. The environment in la Piedra young people's dreams and aspirations, which would be realized in most other places in the world with a little hard work and determination. Most children in la Piedra are not even aware of the possibility that they can become anything more than slum dwellers, petty thieves, prostitutes or gardeners for the nearby mansion or work only the construction industry, because they will never get Dominican birth certificate. We want to change this predicament and give them an opportunity through education - the only leveler in society. With an education opportunities to succeed can be made possible. “Education is a companion which no future can depress, no crime can destroy, no enemy can alienate it and no nepotism can enslave.”
 
Promoting Stability in the Guanin Community Center
 
The school tackles the following three issues to promote stability:
 
1) Ethnic Conflict: La Piedra has 100 people, 60% Haitian descent. Was founded to incorporate people from all different backgrounds. Some of the oldest residents here remember life in La Piedra (its name, appropriately, translates as "The Rock") in the 1940s, around 70 years ago, when all the nearby Ingenio San Luis sugar lands and the undeveloped lands around them were a small part of the vast estates of "El Presidente" Rafael Leónidas Trujillo, the fierce dictator who ruled the Dominican Republic from 1930-1961. After Trujillo´s assassination in May of 1961, the Dominican government laid claim to all the surrounding land and promptly sold thousands of square meters of it to an international or U.S. This library is able to attract youths from many different quarters.
 
2) Gender disparities: La Piedra is in dire need of community-building projects. Having realized that women are the change-makers in low-income communities, The Guanin Community Center has placed a strong emphasis on recruiting and catering to women. Currently the student body is comprised 60% of women. The school has a boarding-house for its girls, who live in la Piedra under the daily risk of gender violence and sexual assaults either en route to their homes, after school or in their homes themselves.
 
3) Vocational Training: Students must be given an education that goes beyond humanities and the liberal arts and sciences. The main reason for the high rate of high school dropouts is their inability to financially support themselves as full-time students. They need to be able to learn trades with which to support their immediate needs. To this end, the curriculum was constructed to include vocational skills and allow students to meet short-term demands. The skills include: farming, small-engine repair, simple architecture, micro-finance, carpentry, brick construction skills, animal husbandry and etc.
 
Project's Impact
 
Project Implementation: Guanin Community Center Library at la Piedra 
 
As part of a global social entrepreneurship initiative designed to create highly motivating, low cost ways to improve educational opportunities in the developing world, we will orchestrate the building of ‘Guanin Community Center Library’ in the summer of 2012 (June 22) to supplement the education.
 
(1) Economy Boosting 
 
 
 
Labor: For the specialized jobs such as welding and electric wiring we will hire a team from Santo Domingo Capital. We will provide jobs for the community members and all our volunteers for the Summer Camp, that do not require technical skill to help build the library, including: painting, excavation, and heavy lifting. This will offer many of the students a head-start on their future vocational training with some first-hand experience. Their involvement will also aid in fostering a sense of ownership. Furniture and Fixtures: We will purchase doors, window frames, windows, desks and chairs from the local industrial area that produces the low-cost material.
 
(2) Community Building and Long-Term Sustainability 
 
Murals: We will organize community activities that don’t require specialized labor (i.e., artwork). Murals will illustrate our tradition, getting the community as involved as possible and providing students with a sense of ownership. Our paid labor will construct the building; the students will add the personal touch, turning it into a library that they can take pride in.
 
Books: The children of la Piedra currently have access to very few used books, most of which the kids have read a few times over. To help further their education, we will be supplying the library with over one thousand textbooks to cater for our three goals:
 
a) One, helping the Dominican-Haitian community to read and write.
 
b) Two, literacy program for youths and adults Certificate of Secondary Education.
 
c) Three, promoting gender equality as women have proven to be strong agents of community-building. We will buy and get these books from the Dominican Ministry of Education. On top of the curriculum books that the students will use, we will get computer and internet service. More books were specifically picked to provide the students with income-generating basic skills (e.g., farming, small engine repair, simple architecture, micro-finance, carpentry, brick laying, and animal husbandry). We concentrate on these income-generating skills because they provide short-term benefits that alleviate the abject poverty in the DR leading to lower dropout rates and keeping students in school for the long run.
 
(3) Cost-Effective Materials in line with the Governing By-Laws of the Dominican Republic County Council 
 
Shipping Containers: We will be using shipping containers because; we can receive books, computers and school supply free tax. Guanin Center, Inc. is a non-profit Dominican organization and we are also registered as a non-profit, charitable organization in the USA under the IRS (501c3).
 
Through the joint effort from the library and school, the students will not just engage in academics, but also vocational training. Involvement in carpentry, tailor work and small-scale farming, English and etc., can bring short-term returns to keep students motivated and long-term benefits to education. Education is fundamental for helping to break the perpetual poverty cycle in the Dominican Republic and Haiti. Through the youth, this knowledge will spread through the close-knit shanty-towns. The Guanin Community Center Library is an ethnic and community building enterprises that will create a space where young minds can be molded to realize that there are more similarities between the two genders and the different ethnic groups than there are differences.
 
What We Need
 
The expenses of building the library and filling it with books will require $10,000. We realize this is a hefty sum of money, but we are all extremely dedicated to reaching our goal. Due to the small size of the group, each member must work as hard as possible to procure as much money as possible to make this project happen.
 
We are raising funds in three phases:
 
a) First, procuring funds to fix and building structure to build one side in block and segment, the old truck the first Dominican Lady donated to us 1 year ago;
 
b) Second, fund-raising for the furniture to be used in the library;
 
c) Third, procuring funds for buying books and purchasing shipping containers of school supply.
 
Every donation, regardless of size will truly help make a difference! We ask you to kindly consider this and please help support our mission! Each and every one of us knows that without your kind help, and many others', this could not happen. Thank you so incredibly much.
 
The Team
 
Guanin Center volunteers.
 
www.guanin.org

story:
Our Story

Living with a Ghanian family, I’ve twice learned how important cultural immersion can be to a student’s development. Educationally, no experience can teach a young adult as much about his/herself as really understanding how other cultures live, learn and work.

 

As a high school teacher in Brooklyn now, I am fund-raising to bring a small group of students to Ghana to experience a culture far from the urban borough of New York City. The students are expected to raise a significant amount of the money on their own, but many come from lower-income families who will need help in this process. With less than a year to finish our fundraising, a little help from you can go a long way for us.

 

The Impact

Partnering with a sister school in Ghana, we have already established a relationship that let’s our students distance-learn with peer students. But this campaign will provide opportunities for lower-income, minority students from the inner city to really experience a culture far different from their own. Teaching on specific subjects relevant to both Brooklyn and Ghana, the students will improve their public speaking skills, learn different governmental structures, learn the importance of bio-diversity, and better understand prevention techniques for and past affects of AIDS/HIV, among other relevant subjects. While the families of the students are contributing much of the money for each student’s experience, many families cannot afford the entire amount and will be forced to revoke their child's enrollment in this awesome opportunity if the funds are not raised.

 

What We Need & What You Get

It costs about $3,200 to send one student to Ghana. Ten students are committed to attending this trip, totaling over $30,000 for the entire experience. Our goal here is to help raise $5000 to offset transportation costs to get the students from New York to Ghana. (With discounts, it will still cost about $1800 for one round-trip ticket.)

 

Some unique perks that result from your donations include:

Postcard from Ghana with a picture of our group

Glass-bead bracelet, hand-strung in Ghana

Hand-written letter from a student while in Ghana

11x14in Fine Art Print photographed by Jessica McClish

Exclusive Ghanaian hand-woven cloth, designed for and traditionally worn by nobility

Dinner with the group so they can teach you more about Ghana (a three-course meal of traditional African food)

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Tweet, facebook, text, chant, email, call, sing, and loudspeaker this to anyone you know!

 

Also, a friend of mine who sells fair trade African gifts/products has graciously volunteered to donate a portion of sales to this fundraiser. If you're interested, check out his site:

www.villagemarketsofafrica.com

After entering a shipping address and selecting a shipping method, there is a pink fundraising credit box...please enter "Discover Ghana" to raise money for my students through your purchase!

If you have questions, please feel free to email jmcclish@williamsburgprep.org

Finally, leave us a note in the Comments section; we would love to meet you :)

story:
We are MIT engineers untapping the vast potential in minority girls to become future STEM (science, technology, engineering, mathematics) leaders by using dance's transformational power to equip them with the educational foundation, empowerment, skills, and character to pursue a STEM education.

HOW

How will we use the money? 

  • $500 pilot program covering costs for study supplies, refreshments, background screening, dance mirrors
  • $3500 full program covering costs for all of the above for more students plus dance instructor, math/science coach, projector, liability insurance

WHAT

What does it look like? see more details here

Monday - Thursday

  • 1.5 hours Math/Science Lab
  • 1.5 hours Dance Studio

Friday

  • STEM Day

What will the impact be? In the short term, students will become proficient in math/science courses, gain bold enthusiasm for STEM, and have increased confidence in the ability to excel in STEM. In the long term, SFD will produce a generation of young women of color who pursue STEM undergraduate degrees. Visit our blog at learn more, and this page in particular to hear about our combination of dance and STEM.

WHEN

When will it begin? We are launching a pilot on September 24, which is why we need to meet our goal by 8/31/2012!

WHERE

Where is it taking place? We are starting in Brooklyn, but in the long-term we hope to expand across the country. ***SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT: We are proud to annouce that WATCH High School has emphatically signed on to host our pilot program. Shout out to the principal of WATCH, Kim Wanliss, for her magnanimous support of our mission!

WHY

Why is our project worth your hard-earned dollars? How about this - we'll give you many reasons why, released throughout the duration of the campaign on the COMMENTS tab. Stay tuned!

WHO

Who are we?

Yamilée Toussaint, founder 

Yamilée has personally experienced the extraordinary benefits of a STEM education and dance. After studying mechanical engineering at MIT and being an avid dancer for 21 years, she switched gears to teach high school algebra in an under-served community in East New York, Brooklyn. As a teacher, her eyes were opened to the multitude of opportunities her students didn't have access to; there was an abundance of potential that would never be unleashed. Therefore, she set out to provide students with something greater than what the school system could provide. She started STEM From Dance with the hope that a strong dance and STEM supplemental education would help to increase the number of under-represented minority high school girls across the nation who pursue a STEM undergraduate education.  When not working on SFD she works on Teach For America's Growth, Development, and Partnerships team, managing the receipt of $270 million donations annually.

Nia Beckley, founding board member

Nia is the epitome of what SFD students can become. With a chemical engineering B.S. and a biological engineering M.Eng from MIT, she is a research scientist at Genentech helping to develop the next generation of oncology and immunology therapies. She attributes much her success through high school and college to the combination of a dance and STEM education, which taught her the skills necessary to become a confident and creative leader. She values the importance of education, particularly increasing the number of underrepresented minorities in STEM fields, and through numerous program, has tutored and taught students from this target demographic in math, chemistry, and reading.  

We'd love to hear from you at stemfromdance@gmail.com

story:
Short Summary

My name is Amilia. In 2008, I became Director of Someone Worth Accepting Now and started The Butterfly House. I am a full time volunteer. SWAN is an organization supporting victims of abuse, completely through individual donors and volunteers. This is important because it means every bit that is donated goes straight to those in need and not to any salaries.

Every month, we spend time and energy to put together fundraising events, to raise the funds needed to support the families calling us. We support and assist women and children fleeing abuse in a lot of different ways. We help with basic needs such as food, clothing and utilities. We also give families furniture, toys and toiletries. We assist in emergencies with tires and other needs to commute to work. SWAN holds support groups for women to heal from their abuse, and in addition, we have  the Butterfly House, our shelter, that is like no other! We provide families with a wonderful place to heal and to change their lives and live violence free.

We want to open a Thrift/Consignment store. This will be a great place for the families to come get what they need (free for them), while also selling items to the public to raise funds needed to continue our services. We would love to see a regular income come from the store, so we no longer need to plan and put on fundraisers every month. We plan on running this as volunteers, and not needing the overhead of wages.

I cannot express enough how important your help is. SWAN has assisted hundreds of families the last few years, and we could help so many more, if our energy was not put into planning fundraisers every month! Everyone will benefit. People in the community can shop a quality store and get items they need while knowing they are directly supporting families in crisis.

What We Need & What You Get

We need at least $5,000 to start up our store.

Just to open, we need things such as shelving, register, lights, deposit for space and electric, insurance, computers, and all the great "set up" costs. Amilia is quite thrifty, and can put all this together for about $5,000, which is really cheap for a fundraising business startup.

First, by contributing you will get the wonderful feeling of knowing you have impacted the lives of others!

All ll levels of support will come with a heartfelt thank you card!

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

Just can’t contribute? That doesn’t mean you can’t help.

Make some noise!

Get this out to ALL your friends and help us get people to this page!
