story:
What Happened?

Malala Yousafzai, a 14 year old girl, and an outspoken activist for girls' education was shot in the head and neck while she sat with classmates on a school bus as it prepared to drive students home after morning classes in Mingora, a city in the Swat valley of Pakistan. 

Police said a man approached the bus and asked which of the girls was Malala. When one of the girls pointed at her, she denied it. The gunman shot both girls. Malala is currently in critical condition and struggling to stay alive.

A Taliban spokesman, Ehsanullah Ehsan, claimed responsibility on behalf of the Pakistani Taliban. Among other horrific things, the terrorist group is notorious for its restrictions of women's freedom and female education.

The Taliban had previously announced she was on their "hit list".

What We Want To Do About It

We want to help ensure that Malala's dream of girls having a chance to be educated in Pakistan stays alive. This barbaric act must not go unanswered. We believe the best way to achieve this goal is to help fund schools in Malala's honor in Pakistan and we need your help.

How You Can Help

If you are in a position to donate money towards the cause, then please do so. If you are not, please help to spread the word about this campaign via e-mail, Facebook, Twitter, Google + or using any other method you can.

Use this URL: http://www.indiegogo.com/malala to spread the word.

The Urgency

Attention quickly fades, even from the most horrific acts. Usually another horrific act is not far behind. We need everyone to donate and get the word out NOW, so we don't miss the opportunity while this tragedy is still fresh in the minds of people across the world. Our urgent action will help to ensure that a lasting institution will be built to help keep Malala's dream alive. 

The Details

We are proud to announce that all funds raised through this campaign will be donated to Developments in Literacy (DIL). The funds will be allocated specifically to funding education in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, the province where Malala lives. DIL operates 34 schools in the province where Malala lives and where she was attacked. DIL educates and empowers underprivileged students, especially girls, by operating student-centered model schools; and provides high-quality professional development to teachers and principals across Pakistan. 

 

 

The DIL statement on this campaign:

The attack on Malala is shocking and shameful. Her bravery and leadership are an inspiration. DIL schools provide quality education to thousands of girls like Malala, empowering them to become leaders and citizens and speak up confidently for their rights. The organization operates 179 school units across Pakistan, educating 17,062 children, of which 68% are girls. There are 34 DIL schools in the Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KPK) province, where female literacy is held back by difficult mountainous terrain, lack of roads, and conservative tribal traditions. It costs DIL $100 a year to educate a child. Honor Malala today by supporting quality education for girls. 

More Details on Developments in Literacy (DIL):

DIL operates under the auspices of a US-based Board of Directors and a Pakistan-based Board of Trustees. DIL was granted tax-exempt status 501 (c) (3) by the IRS in February 2000.

DIL was registered in July 2000 in Pakistan under the Societies Registration Act 1860 and donations received in Pakistan are tax-exempt.  All members of the Board of Directors and the Board of Trustees are volunteers and serve without compensation.

What New York Times columnist Nicolas Kristof (Half the Sky) thinks of DIL:

"Developments in Literacy, www.dil.org, builds terrific modern schools in Pakistan, particularly for girls. It frustrates me that rural Pakistan abounds with hard-line madrassas financed by fundamentalist Muslims who channel the students toward extremism. Extremists recognize the transformative power of education, and so should we. This is a security issue, for D.I.L. schools can help protect us from terrorism." (http://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/24/opinion/24kristof.html)

 

Links:

DIL website: http://www.dil.org

DIL e-mail: office@dil.org

DIL phone number: 949-474-5303

DIL Charity Navigator Ranking: http://www.charitynavigator.org/index.cfm?bay=search.summary&orgid=9923

 

Please use the hashtag: #malala
story_txt:
What Happened?
Malala Yousafzai, a 14 year old girl, and an outspoken activist for girls' education was shot in the head and neck while she sat with classmates on a school bus as it prepared to drive students home after morning classes in Mingora, a city in the Swat valley of Pakistan. 
Police said a man approached the bus and asked which of the girls was Malala. When one of the girls pointed at her, she denied it. The gunman shot both girls. Malala is currently in critical condition and struggling to stay alive.
A Taliban spokesman, Ehsanullah Ehsan, claimed responsibility on behalf of the Pakistani Taliban. Among other horrific things, the terrorist group is notorious for its restrictions of women's freedom and female education.
The Taliban had previously announced she was on their "hit list".


What We Want To Do About It
We want to help ensure that Malala's dream of girls having a chance to be educated in Pakistan stays alive. This barbaric act must not go unanswered. We believe the best way to achieve this goal is to help fund schools in Malala's honor in Pakistan and we need your help.
How You Can Help
If you are in a position to donate money towards the cause, then please do so. If you are not, please help to spread the word about this campaign via e-mail, Facebook, Twitter, Google + or using any other method you can.
Use this URL: http://www.indiegogo.com/malala to spread the word.


The Urgency
Attention quickly fades, even from the most horrific acts. Usually another horrific act is not far behind. We need everyone to donate and get the word out NOW, so we don't miss the opportunity while this tragedy is still fresh in the minds of people across the world. Our urgent action will help to ensure that a lasting institution will be built to help keep Malala's dream alive. 


The Details
We are proud to announce that all funds raised through this campaign will be donated to Developments in Literacy (DIL). The funds will be allocated specifically to funding education in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, the province where Malala lives. DIL operates 34 schools in the province where Malala lives and where she was attacked. DIL educates and empowers underprivileged students, especially girls, by operating student-centered model schools; and provides high-quality professional development to teachers and principals across Pakistan. 



 

 
The DIL statement on this campaign:
The attack on Malala is shocking and shameful. Her bravery and leadership are an inspiration. DIL schools provide quality education to thousands of girls like Malala, empowering them to become leaders and citizens and speak up confidently for their rights. The organization operates 179 school units across Pakistan, educating 17,062 children, of which 68% are girls. There are 34 DIL schools in the Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KPK) province, where female literacy is held back by difficult mountainous terrain, lack of roads, and conservative tribal traditions. It costs DIL $100 a year to educate a child. Honor Malala today by supporting quality education for girls. 
More Details on Developments in Literacy (DIL):
DIL operates under the auspices of a US-based Board of Directors and a Pakistan-based Board of Trustees. DIL was granted tax-exempt status 501 (c) (3) by the IRS in February 2000.
DIL was registered in July 2000 in Pakistan under the Societies Registration Act 1860 and donations received in Pakistan are tax-exempt.  All members of the Board of Directors and the Board of Trustees are volunteers and serve without compensation.
What New York Times columnist Nicolas Kristof (Half the Sky) thinks of DIL:
"Developments in Literacy, www.dil.org, builds terrific modern schools in Pakistan, particularly for girls. It frustrates me that rural Pakistan abounds with hard-line madrassas financed by fundamentalist Muslims who channel the students toward extremism. Extremists recognize the transformative power of education, and so should we. This is a security issue, for D.I.L. schools can help protect us from terrorism." (http://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/24/opinion/24kristof.html)
 
Links:
DIL website: http://www.dil.org
DIL e-mail: office@dil.org
DIL phone number: 949-474-5303
DIL Charity Navigator Ranking: http://www.charitynavigator.org/index.cfm?bay=search.summary&orgid=9923
 
Please use the hashtag: #malala

story:
Ciao Family & Friends,

It has been an amazing time at the world of Wellesley College as I am already in my junior year! I am reaching out to my village because I have been accepted to study abroad in Bologna, Italy this upcoming Winter/Spring semester. I began studying Italian my first semester at Wellesley College and fell in love with the richness of literature and the extraordinary history of the Italian culture. Next to Spanish, it is my second foreign language that I speak, write and comprehend fluidly. I felt that I needed to embark on a journey that could help me to develop my skills to compliment my major of Women and Gender studies with an emphasis on bioethics pre med and global public health. I will enrich my knowledge of Italy with first-hand experience, and I have been awarded the opportunity to explore and am ready for the challenge. In order to fully enjoy this amazing opportunity, I need to raise $5,500.00 which helps to pay for the study abroad program two semesters. As most of you know my 20th birthday is November 19th, I would greatly appreciate it if you would consider contributing to the fund or perhaps make it an early holiday gift as I leave the first week in January 2015.

As always, I take nothing for granted as it truly takes a village to raise a child. Thank you in advance for your continual prayers, love, commitment and support in helping me to fulfill my goal to become a doctor, agent for change and citizen of the world. I really do believe that "service is the rent that we pay for the space that we occupy in the world." :D

Grazie a Mille (Thanks a lot),

Jordan Stephens-Moseley aka Jojo and Joy Joy

story:
Short Summary

My birth name is "Chris" and my dharma name is "ShoYu", which means "genuine/authentic friend", and I am a practicing Zen Buddhist.

I have wanted to become a monk for several years, because the world needs people dedicated healing suffering and I have long felt pushed by an invisible force towards that path. The only reason I didn't become a monk years ago was because I had a romantic relationship that was so wonderful, that I simply was not willing to give it up.

In April, my beautiful partner of 8 years passed away. Her death was the most painful experience of my life, but it was also the cutting of the last tie that held me to the secular world. Since that fateful day in April, I have dedicated my life entirely towards healing the suffering off all beings (including my own).

My good friend, Jawoo Sunim, runs a small temple in Seoul and has agreed to allow me to work at her temple and has already made lodging arrangements for me at a local monastery.

What is Needed & What You Get

This fund will purchase a plane ticket to Seoul Korea where I will spend 3 months in a monastery deepening my understanding of the dharma and teaching English to the Korean monastic community.

Perks for donors are as follows:

  • Daily prayer and incense offering for you for the length of the pilgrimage
  • Handwritten thank you letter with picture and a special prayer card
  • Mala (prayer beads) made and blessed by me!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute, you can still help:

  • Help make some noise about this campaign
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you very much!

story:
Code For Humanity

While there are many organizations worldwide that are dedicated to giving everyone access to general education, technology education is essentially nonexistent in developing countries.  

While basic education is a crucial first step to empowering individuals in developing countries, technology education is an essential next step to help connect these people with the world and create businesses that have the ability to grow.  Particularly for entrepreneurs and business people, access to technology has increasingly become the difference between success and failure.  Code For Humanity has and continues to fill this niche and giving entrepreneurs worldwide the opportunity for success. 

As entrepreneurs ourselves, we were struck by others' inability to have these same opportunities: no matter how much passion we encountered, there simply were not the resources to act on their ideas.

Although Nosy Be is one of the wealthiest regions of Madagascar, it remains one of the poorest in the world, and foreign businesses and investors capture the majority of the wealth.  Locally-owned hotels and businesses suffer from a lack of international publicity and are overshadowed by their foreign-owned competitors.  And with over 77% of Malagasy people living under the poverty line, there are few viable economic alternatives: many individuals have lost much of their autonomy in choosing a livelihood.

Empowerment of entrepreneurship is a means to end these problems, and Code for Humanity sets out to create an infrastructure and a community that can create their own futures. 

Our mission is to empower individuals on Nosy Be to create their own opportunity for economic, personal, or community growth.  Our strategy to accomplish this is through provision of computer education that is practical, affordable, and relevant. Particularly, we provide courses in technology and web development which allow new organizations to build a foundation and existing organizations to grow.



The Impact

Our initial 10-week program in Nosy Be was a huge success: with 11 graduates who created websites supporting entrepreneurial endeavors ranging from hotels, to restaurants, to dance clubs, to eco-tourism.  Many of these students had not used computers before, and the products they were able to create after a mere 10 weeks were astonishing.  See their websites here.


We are so proud of our 11 graduates, but we know that there are more than 11 entrepreneurs in Madagascar who would benefit from learning the skills that will allow them to make their dreams become realities. Even at our farewell party and awards ceremony, there were students who came to express their interest in upcoming classes.

Now, we need your help giving those students an opportunity for a better future.

During our last program, we trained three highly-competent teachers to run the upcoming classes of Code for Humanity in Madagascar.  What we lack, however, is a space in which to host the program, and the internet connection to make web design classes possible. 



That’s where you come in.  We have the students, the teachers, and the passion.  All we need is a leg up to help set up a sustainable infrastructure that will allow us to continue operations without need for future donations.


The Impact

Our initial class was a huge success, and we're ready to do more!  

At Code for Humanity, it is important to us to strive for high returns for low costs.

Our sustainable structure allows us to continue operating at a low costs, which means your money will go a long way. 

Tell us where you want your donation to go! We’ll make sure your money goes to support the part of Code for Humanity you care about most.

  1) $450 to build a CFH schoolroom

  2) $220 pays for a new CFH computer

  3) $25 internet for a month

  4) $10 pay for a student to attend a full CFH workshop


  Operating Costs Code for Humanity:

But wait, it gets better: Your donation will not only help us cover these very important operational costs, it will also help us set up a sustainable framework for our organization that will allow us to continue programs in the future without further donation!  Yours is a gift that will keep on giving. 


    Other Ways You Can Help

    Even if you can’t donate money today, there are still so many ways to help out Code for Humanity and the people of Nosy Be. 

    1)  Help us get the word out! Share this campaign by Facebook or Email

    2)  Let us know if you have any materials you’d be willing to contribute (old laptops, ipads, ect)

    3)  Get in touch with us about volunteering as a teacher at one of our programs

    Also, feel free to email us here or at codeforhumanity2014@gmail.com if you are interested in a partnership with Code for Humanity, or if you would like to donate but cannot or do not wish to do so online.

    Thank you, from the bottoms of our hearts, for your time, consideration, and support.

    “Misoatra Betsaka!”

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
I can't believe it.  

I've been accepted to a Global Leaders Program called Hive! 

Hive will help take my leadership skills to a whole new level so I can help hundreds of girls through #GirlsRising. But I know I can’t do it myself.  I need you.  I need your  support because to get into this program, I have to raise $1,200 in 8 days.

 

 

I have 2 donors willing to give me $300 each if you can help me raise another $300 in the FIRST THREE DAYS of my campaign (by Wednesday).

If we can do that -- that’s $900 toward my goal of $1200.  Then, I’ll only have to raise $300 more dollars.

PLEASE HELP ME REACH MY GOAL BY BACKING THE CAMPAIGN AT $25, $50, or a $100 TODAY.

But first, let me introduce myself.

 

My story

 

 

 

I'm Olivia. You've probably seen photos of me traveling. Maybe we went to college together. Perhaps we're childhood friends.  One way or another, you know me.  And I know you. 

It's been hard to keep in touch; I know.  I don't blame you if you've deleted my contact info because every time you reach out you get a reply, "returned to sender." 

Well, that's because, for the last six years, I've been exploring a lot of different things.  I majored in International Relations, but when I graduated college, I really didn't have any relations internationally.  So I set out to study the world. 

Since then, I've worked for a variety of nonprofits, found one of my own -- which was recognized by the Clinton Foundation -- built a soccer field for a school in Nepal, and researched nuclear radiation in Japan. Last summer, I backpacked the Middle East alone and led a project in a Syrian refugee camp with the support of the United Nations.

 

You may be familiar with Zaatari in Al Mafraq, Jordan. Angelina Jolie and UN Secretary-General, Ban Ki-Moon's visits last year brought great international attention to this Syrian refugee camp.

 

 

Fatima and Ezra narrowly escaped death and traveled on foot from their hometown in Syria to neighboring Jordan. They would later convince me to start #GirlsRising.

 

 

 

 

This photo was taken just 1 week before chemical weapons were used on the Syrian people. I often think about where these kids are now, and if they're still alive.

 

These girls and boys proved to me that soccer has the power to lift an entire community. I love this picture because it reminds me of my favorite quote by Gandhi, "The best way to find yourself is to lose yourself in the service of others."

 

I love rainy days especially at the Sarswati Peace School in Nepal. I call this photo, "How to read extremely confusing children's pop-up books."
 
 

About Hive

 

 

  

 
 

A unique situation

For the past year, I've been volunteering to serve 250 refugee and immigrant youth using soccer and education while living under the poverty line.  I took a chance, got accepted to Hive, and crossed my fingers thinking: "If there's a will, there's a way." 

However, my tuition is not covered.  If I can't raise the money, I might have to back out.  I'm cringing at the thought of it.  I rather spend winter in Antarctica before retracting my acceptance.

 

What I need and how you can help

I need to raise $1,200. Just so you know, 100% of all the money raised (including anything we get after hitting our goal) will go directly toward leadership development and training.

 

 

 

$1,200 secures:

  • unparalleled education & training at Hive (tuition)
  • food
  • transportation (1 economy class R/T ticket from San Diego to San Francisco)
  • preparatory reading materials
  • conference materials
  • a good night's sleep
 

 

Ways to get involved

  • Back: financially invest in my campaign
  • Advocate: spread the word + share on social media using #getOlivia2Hive
  • Connect: introduce Olivia to people
  • Inspire: talk about the campaign w/ others
  • Host: host a fundraiser, dinner, party, or any event where I can share my story and the story of #GirlsRising
  • Join: become a team member of our campaign

 

Perks, rewards, and reasons to get excited

 

 

 

Here's what you'll get:
  • shout outs on social media
  • shipments of life-changing books
  • personal copies of my book, Stand Up!
  • an intimate experience with the girls who inspired #GirlsRising
  • valuable insights from Hive
  • custom designed postcards

 

Delivering results & high impact

 

     

    100% of ALL donations I received to lead previous initiatives were spent on programs and humanitarian aid.  Check out my track record:

     

     

     

    ---> Fundraised $7K in 1 week, purchased and delivered pre-fabricated shelters to a Syrian refugee camp. 
    Impact: 12 women, children, and elderly people have shelter that will protect them from harsh winds, snow, rain, and sun stroke for at least 3-5 years.
     
    ---> Found 2 "Commitment to Action" projects at the Clinton Global Initiative University.  Outcome: After meeting with President Clinton and 1,400 other social entrepreneurs, 7 of my team members went on to launch their own companies, pursue graduate degrees, and teach English abroad as Fulbright scholars.

    ---> Designed a $10K award-winning project.  Implemented it in a Himalayan village.  Impact: 250 children played organized soccer for the 1st time and gained access to computers, books and toothbrushes.

    ---> Helped the nonprofit, YALLA grow their budget by 760% in just 11 months.     Impact: 300 refugee and immigrant youth will graduate from middle and high school thanks to new computer tablets which will enable them to study at their own pace.
     
    Other Awards
    • Awarded a $20K scholarship (Boren) from the US government to study a language deemed critical to national security.
    •  My featured story in "Stand Up! 75 Young Activists Who Rock the World And How You Can, Too!" won the Nautilus and INDIEFAB Book of the Year Award in 2012.

       

      A personal testimony from a CNN Hero: Mark Kabban

      "Olivia has a high emotional intelligence, it gives her authenticity, perspective, and a quality that often made me come to her for solutions; her door was always open. She is on her way to making her mark on this world, and I hope to stay a part of it."  

       Mark Kabban, CNN Hero  & Founder of YALLA

           

      My backup plan

      • Flight cancellation or delay?  Pack the car and hit the road 24 hrs before.
      • Didn't reach fundraising goal?  Put it on credit.  Figure out details later.
      • Fundraising page crashes from too much traffic?  Celebrate!  Then rebuild.
      • Logistical problems?  Group text my 5-person support team.
      • Face opposition?  Keep calm and carry on.  But be sure to ask for feedback.

         

        Other Ways You Can Help

        Some people don't have the means to contribute at this time.  But that doesn't mean you can't help.  Folks, you can still get the word out and make some noise.

         

        Bloggers who are using their online presence to elevate the campaign and #GirlsRising

        • Philippe Lazaro
        • Just4notherBlog: A Blog About Entrepreneurship. And Rarely More.

But first, let me introduce myself.
 
My story
 
 
 

I'm Olivia. You've probably seen photos of me traveling. Maybe we went to college together. Perhaps we're childhood friends.  One way or another, you know me.  And I know you. 
It's been hard to keep in touch; I know.  I don't blame you if you've deleted my contact info because every time you reach out you get a reply, "returned to sender." 
Well, that's because, for the last six years, I've been exploring a lot of different things.  I majored in International Relations, but when I graduated college, I really didn't have any relations internationally.  So I set out to study the world. 
Since then, I've worked for a variety of nonprofits, found one of my own -- which was recognized by the Clinton Foundation -- built a soccer field for a school in Nepal, and researched nuclear radiation in Japan. Last summer, I backpacked the Middle East alone and led a project in a Syrian refugee camp with the support of the United Nations.
 

You may be familiar with Zaatari in Al Mafraq, Jordan. Angelina Jolie and UN Secretary-General, Ban Ki-Moon's visits last year brought great international attention to this Syrian refugee camp. 
 

Fatima and Ezra narrowly escaped death and traveled on foot from their hometown in Syria to neighboring Jordan. They would later convince me to start #GirlsRising.
 
 
 

 
This photo was taken just 1 week before chemical weapons were used on the Syrian people. I often think about where these kids are now, and if they're still alive.
 

These girls and boys proved to me that soccer has the power to lift an entire community. I love this picture because it reminds me of my favorite quote by Gandhi, "The best way to find yourself is to lose yourself in the service of others."
 

I love rainy days especially at the Sarswati Peace School in Nepal. I call this photo, "How to read extremely confusing children's pop-up books."      

About Hive

 

 
  

 
 
A unique situation
For the past year, I've been volunteering to serve 250 refugee and immigrant youth using soccer and education while living under the poverty line.  I took a chance, got accepted to Hive, and crossed my fingers thinking: "If there's a will, there's a way." 
However, my tuition is not covered.  If I can't raise the money, I might have to back out.  I'm cringing at the thought of it.  I rather spend winter in Antarctica before retracting my acceptance.
 

What I need and how you can help
I need to raise $1,200. Just so you know, 100% of all the money raised (including anything we get after hitting our goal) will go directly toward leadership development and training.
 
 
 
$1,200 secures:

unparalleled education & training at Hive (tuition)
food
transportation (1 economy class R/T ticket from San Diego to San Francisco)
preparatory reading materials
conference materials
a good night's sleep

 

 
Ways to get involved


Back: financially invest in my campaign

Advocate: spread the word + share on social media using #getOlivia2Hive

Connect: introduce Olivia to people

Inspire: talk about the campaign w/ others

Host: host a fundraiser, dinner, party, or any event where I can share my story and the story of #GirlsRising

Join: become a team member of our campaign


 
Perks, rewards, and reasons to get excited

 

 

 Here's what you'll get:
shout outs on social media
shipments of life-changing books
personal copies of my book, Stand Up!
an intimate experience with the girls who inspired #GirlsRising
valuable insights from Hive
custom designed postcards


 
Delivering results & high impact

 


 

100% of ALL donations I received to lead previous initiatives were spent on programs and humanitarian aid.  Check out my track record: 
 
 


---> Fundraised $7K in 1 week, purchased and delivered pre-fabricated shelters to a Syrian refugee camp. Impact: 12 women, children, and elderly people have shelter that will protect them from harsh winds, snow, rain, and sun stroke for at least 3-5 years. 

---> Found 2 "Commitment to Action" projects at the Clinton Global Initiative University.  Outcome: After meeting with President Clinton and 1,400 other social entrepreneurs, 7 of my team members went on to launch their own companies, pursue graduate degrees, and teach English abroad as Fulbright scholars.


---> Designed a $10K award-winning project.  Implemented it in a Himalayan village.  Impact: 250 children played organized soccer for the 1st time and gained access to computers, books and toothbrushes.


---> Helped the nonprofit, YALLA grow their budget by 760% in just 11 months.     Impact: 300 refugee and immigrant youth will graduate from middle and high school thanks to new computer tablets which will enable them to study at their own pace.

 

Other Awards
Awarded a $20K scholarship (Boren) from the US government to study a language deemed critical to national security.

 My featured story in "Stand Up! 75 Young Activists Who Rock the World And How You Can, Too!" won the Nautilus and INDIEFAB Book of the Year Award in 2012.




 A personal testimony from a CNN Hero: Mark Kabban"Olivia has a high emotional intelligence, it gives her authenticity, perspective, and a quality that often made me come to her for solutions; her door was always open. She is on her way to making her mark on this world, and I hope to stay a part of it."  
 Mark Kabban, CNN Hero  & Founder of YALLA
     

My backup plan


Flight cancellation or delay?  Pack the car and hit the road 24 hrs before.

Didn't reach fundraising goal?  Put it on credit.  Figure out details later.

Fundraising page crashes from too much traffic?  Celebrate!  Then rebuild.

Logistical problems?  Group text my 5-person support team.

Face opposition?  Keep calm and carry on.  But be sure to ask for feedback.



 
Other Ways You Can Help
Some people don't have the means to contribute at this time.  But that doesn't mean you can't help.  Folks, you can still get the word out and make some noise.
 
Bloggers who are using their online presence to elevate the campaign and #GirlsRising

Philippe Lazaro
Just4notherBlog: A Blog About Entrepreneurship. And Rarely More.

story:
About Us

It’s been over a year since my husband joined the United States Air Force. There are always ups and downs with any changes in life but the hardest thing to deal with is being so far away from our family and friends. We moved from the big city of Phoenix, Arizona to the very small town of Goldsboro, North Carolina (1 hour away from Raleigh). Now we’ve tried to make friends and be a part of the military community but unfortunately it’s been tough to adapt to the change. He works hard every single day and rarely complains but I know that he wishes things were different. Whenever we take a step forward financially, we always have to take two steps back and it’s frustrating. We don’t have a lot to go out or splurge on anything because we’re trying to be debt free. I know he deserves to visit our family and friends and I want to give this to him so badly. Our finances make it difficult to save up for the flights. Reaching our campaign goal will give us just enough to fly roundtrip, so please help us see our loved ones. Every little bit counts!

story:
Hi,

I am Tatiana Barros Boudreaux and the Secretary of BIA- Brazilian International Association of Autism. A non-profit organization 501(c)(3).

Our Mission:

“BIA provides parents of people with autism with guidance and support to help families learn how to cope with the syndrome. We also guide families how and where to find government financial and professional help. BIA aims to become a leading advocate for Brazilian families globally.”

Our Fundraising Campaign: For Rent! – Help International Association of Autism find a new home.

Unexpectedly, we have lost the lease of the place where we have been for the past three years, and are now looking for a new place to rent. During the past years, BIA’s doors have been open to many families that have found themselves facing a complex diagnosis such as autism. Many of them not knowing where to go or who to ask for help. Fortunately for them, Wilma, our founder and president, was there; ready to give them any help and support they needed to cope with it. For example, Zoila, a single mother of Jason, a 14-year-old boy, diagnosed with autistc spectrum disorder. For her, BIA is the only place she has to turn to, and they listen to her, and help her during moments of depression and difficulties. In her own words "they give me strength to keep on going raising my son."

Wilma has been in their shoes, when she supported her sister coping with her son with autistic spectrum disorder, researching about the syndrome and seeking any assistance her nephew needed and still needs to this day. Wilma’s personal experience and knowledge has motivated her to found BIA and enabled her to provide guidance and support to many families to this day. BIA has grown in many ways, and we are now a large group and a home where we’ve fostered a sense of family and togetherness.

Now, we need to find a new place where we can give continuity to what we have built, and we need your help.



What We Need & What You Get

  • We need your help raising $10.000,00 USD that will cover any moving and expenses, including: truck rental, movers, and boxes; cleaning; real stated agent fee; deposit/moving fee, 1st month rent; new storage/shelves;  organization containers; furniture; child proofing the space; decorating the space autism friendly; perks, and shipping cost. Your donation are tax deductible.
  • We give unique perks. Perks are a gift you receive for being awesome! We have Autism Awareness perks so you can show people you care. We also give Kid’s artwork as perks so you can have something unique to show off  to your friends. The artworks were made at our art studio with clay and paper maché. For larger donations we give free admission to our Annual BBQ in July, and gift cards to restaurants. The cherry on the cake is a dinner with our very own founder Wilma Andrade.  You can check out more about it on the Perks page.
  • If we don’t reach our entire goal, we will use what we got where we can, and raise what we need some other way but we need to find us a place. 


The Impact

This campaign aims to accommodate our growing needs so we can continue to provide guidance and support to the many families that seek our help. Your contribution is not only appreciated but it affects the lives and well being of many of these families. 

  • In 2014 BIA has acted as an advocated for many families connecting their kids with all necessary therapies so that they can better develop with autism syndrome. These therapies are provided by the government and are very helpful to the children.
  • In 2013, BIA has assisted a grandmother on a custody case of her two autistic grandsons, both whom participates at activities held a BIA’s. With BIA’s help the grandmother has been granted custody of her grandchildren.
  • In that same year, BIA helped a non-English speaking family who were having difficulties explaining to the school about their autistic son’s behavior. BIA helped the parents with translation explaining the special needs to their child and asking for an adequate accommodation.


Other Ways You Can Help

  • You can help us move. We will need men power and trucks so if you want to help please contact us. 
  • Spread the word. If you know anyone who can help us reach our goal, please share our campaign with them. We appreciate!

story:
Bring TECHNE to California & Texas! 

Since 2013, TECHNE’s summer tour has brought their DIY electronic music workshops to hundreds of young women at Girls Rock Camps and community arts centers in across the US. From Oakland, Sacramento, Portland and Seattle to Murfreesboro, Philadelphia, New Orleans, Baton Rouge, Washington DC, and South Carolina!

This summer we’re heading to sunny Southern California and Texas! We’ve got special workshops planned for the Girls Rock Santa Barbara sleepaway camp, and contact mic building in Los Angeles, Houston, Dallas and Austin!

Who are Techne and Girls Rock Camp?

TECHNE is an arts education organization founded by musicians Bonnie Jones & Suzanne Thorpe in 2010. We teach workshops combining sound, technology and musical improvisation. Through our programs we empower young women, increase their involvement in technology, and inspire them to engage in creative and innovative music practices that engender confidence building and identity exploration.

Since the first Girls Rock n' Roll Camp was founded in Portland, OR in 2001, GIRLS ROCK CAMPS have sprung up all over the US and abroad including Sweden, Brazil, Canada, and France. All camps share the unifying goal of inspiring self-esteem and mutual support among diverse young girls through musical expression.

More cities and more workshops

This year we're continuing our partnership with several US-based Girls Rock Camps and arts nonprofits with an ambitious goal of presenting 8 workshops in 6 cities including Ojai, Los Angeles, San Diego, Dallas, Houston, and Austin.

In addition to the workshops we’ll be performing a concert in each city, featuring Bonnie & Suzanne in duet, and fellow local female artists. These events will provide much needed modeling of women electronic musicians practicing their craft.

and we need your support...

TECHNE workshops show girls how to build exciting new instruments with DIY electronics, explore creative sound-making techniques, and collaborate together in a fun group improvisation. We also like to sneak in key audio and technology concepts, including an overview of the physics of sound, signal flow, and basic circuitry. Nerd girl alert!

After the workshop, the girls take home a unique, self-crafted instrument and, we hope, a new and fresh perspective on music making and self-expression.

Here's where you come in...

Girls Rock camps are independent and staffed primarily by volunteers. Each camp has to negotiate the various pressures of balancing excellent programming and staff and increasing better access to students with tight and getting tighter budgets.

By contributing to our campaign TECHNE has a chance to provide unique programming without placing additional financial burden on the individual camps.

Your support will enable TECHNE and Girls Rock camps to offer kick-ass workshops in electronic music to young women!

The money situation

TECHNE is honored to receive a $5,000 grant this year from University of California Integrative Research Arts program for our summer workshop tour. In addition, each camp provides reimbursement for basic materials, however we still need to find a way to cover several of our travel, equipment, and instructor fees. We do fundraisers like this so that we can keep workshops cheap or free for these largely volunteer camps.

Our working budget is outlined below so that you know exactly what your contribution will be used towards. 

All your donations are tax-deductible through our fiscal sponsor High Zero Foundation.

  • Airfare and local transportation / $1,700
  • Lodging and meals / $1,900
  • Instructor fees for eight workshops / $3,100
  • Administrative/overhead costs  / $1,500
  • Workshop materials / $1,800
If we are unable to meet our goal of $5,000, we’ll use whatever funds we do receive towards materials, airfare, and local transportation for as many workshops as feasible.


The bigger picture

There’s a gender gap in the world of technology. It’s a fact that women are vastly underrepresented in technology fields including art, science, music, and business.

TECHNE wants to bridge that gap. We want to inspire young women to take that soldering iron, computer mouse or circuit board in hand and feel empowered by their technology skills. We want to be role models for young girls who are interested in electronic music or DIY building but hesitate because of the lack of women in the field.

But most of all, we want to inspire these young women to think critically, experiment freely and discover their own voice.

Your help supports an arts curricula rooted in technology and musical improvisation that is proven to build confidence, self-awareness, group-awareness, and problem solving techniques. If we give them the tools, they will do the rest!

As a token of our gratitude

To thank you for your amazing support TECHNE put together a few tokens of our undying gratitude! Alas, you can't come to the camp (but maybe your daughter can?), but we've got some amazing gifts including limited edition digital downloads (from artists such as Jenny Graf, Okkyung Lee, Philip White, Maria Chavez, and more!), a TECHNE temporary tattoo, and ... wait for it... autographed copies of three Patti Smith books. Are you still waiting? Well stop that and donate now! 

All your donations are tax-deductible through our fiscal sponsor High Zero Foundation and will appear on your bank statement as High Zero Foundation. 
Video: Kristen Anchor                                                                                    Photos: Emma Lee/WHYY    Listen to the interview here.

story:
“…I liked interacting with different debaters from different neighborhoods in different parts of the city. It forced me to leave my comfort zone. ”

Help make our summer debate camp tuition-free for low-income kids. 

Debate is an incredible outlet for young people to find their voice, improve their grades, and transform their lives.

The Chicago Debate Summer Institute (CDSI) makes high-quality pre-season debate training accessible to Chicago students. We are raising funds to provide this two-week intensive high school and middle school debate program TUITION-FREE to low-income students.

The Chicago Debate Commission needs your help raising $10,000 to meet our fundraising goal! This year, with almost 130 students participating, CDSI will cost approximately $75,000. We already have support from Chicago Public Schools and generous private donors but still have a ways to go. That is where you come in!

Summer debate camps have long been a catalyst for kids from affluent backgrounds. But these very expensive camps are out of financial reach for most of Chicago students. Our students deserve access to the advantages that intensive pre-season debate training provide - and CDSI gives our students that access. Institute staff will include some of the nation's most accomplished collegiate and former high school debaters, along with some of the best of our own coaching talent. 

What do students do at CDSI?

Their intensive program introduces new debaters to argument and debate and helps more advanced students refine their debate skills. Students learn about the debate topic of the year. Divided into small groups by skill level, debaters experience labs, lectures, faculty demonstration debates, flowing and speaking drills, practice speeches, mini-debates, and learning games. The camp culminates in a two-day tournament, allowing students to put their skills to immediate competitive use. 

“My favorite part of CDSI was interacting with the lab leaders. They didn’t treat me like a child; they treated me like I was one of them.” 

What is this year's topic at CDSI?

Resolution for 2016-17: The United States Federal Government should substantially increase its economic and/or diplomatic engagement with the People’s Republic of China.

Why is debate and CDSI important?

“I thought I could just sit in the back but they actually made me stand up and debate for the first time – now I have all the confidence to debate all season long.”

Debate is an engaging and exciting competitive activity that takes advantage of adolescents’ interest in argument, learning-by-doing, and social engagement. Debate is research-proven to improve students’ academic results and school engagement – and the more a student participates, the better the results.  CDSI provides an unparalleled opportunity to motivate and improve debate participation for Chicago students:

  • University-based summer debate institutes – long recognized as powerful tools for high school debaters to develop skills and advance their competitive edge – cost thousands of dollars and are financially out-of-reach for most of our students.  CDSI brings the benefits of high-quality summer debate training to Chicago’s students with free tuition for low-income students and modest tuition for other students.
  • CDSI increases student engagement in debate. Participants become excited about starting the season and hit the ground running when debate begins in the fall.
  • CDSI increases student leadership. Participants bring the skills and enthusiasm they gain at CDSI to their peers and rouse them to action. They become their teams’ leaders and mentors for less-experienced students.
  • CDSI increases competitive edge. After CDSI, students feel better prepared to compete and show even greater passion for debate tournament participation.

But these very expensive camps are out of financial reach for most of Chicago students. Our students deserve access to the advantages that intensive pre-season debate training provide - and CDSI gives our students that access. Institute staff will include some of the nation's most accomplished collegiate and former high school debaters, along with some of the best of our own coaching talent. What do students do at CDSI?Their intensive program introduces new debaters to argument and debate and helps more advanced students refine their debate skills. Students learn about the debate topic of the year. Divided into small groups by skill level, debaters experience labs, lectures, faculty demonstration debates, flowing and speaking drills, practice speeches, mini-debates, and learning games. The camp culminates in a two-day tournament, allowing students to put their skills to immediate competitive use. “My favorite part of CDSI was interacting with the lab leaders. They didn’t treat me like a child; they treated me like I was one of them.” What is this year's topic at CDSI?Resolution for 2016-17: The United States Federal Government should substantially increase its economic and/or diplomatic engagement with the People’s Republic of China.Why is debate and CDSI important?“I thought I could just sit in the back but they actually made me stand up and debate for the first time – now I have all the confidence to debate all season long.”Debate is an engaging and exciting competitive activity that takes advantage of adolescents’ interest in argument, learning-by-doing, and social engagement. Debate is research-proven to improve students’ academic results and school engagement – and the more a student participates, the better the results.  CDSI provides an unparalleled opportunity to motivate and improve debate participation for Chicago students:
University-based summer debate institutes – long recognized as powerful tools for high school debaters to develop skills and advance their competitive edge – cost thousands of dollars and are financially out-of-reach for most of our students.  CDSI brings the benefits of high-quality summer debate training to Chicago’s students with free tuition for low-income students and modest tuition for other students.
CDSI increases student engagement in debate. Participants become excited about starting the season and hit the ground running when debate begins in the fall.
CDSI increases student leadership. Participants bring the skills and enthusiasm they gain at CDSI to their peers and rouse them to action. They become their teams’ leaders and mentors for less-experienced students.
CDSI increases competitive edge. After CDSI, students feel better prepared to compete and show even greater passion for debate tournament participation.

story:
Helping Children....Changing Lives

eAmbalam, through Life Art Education, believes that every child has a right to receive truly inspiring holistic education through Music, Dance, Yoga and Personality Development programs. This vision has driven us to partner with Center for Women's Development and Research (CWDR) in working with children of two slums Kannagi Nagar (one of the biggest slums in Chennai)  and Thiruvanmiyur. Our passionate teachers will engage with these underprivileged children for six months starting November 2015 and help them enhance their intellectual, emotional, social, ethical and artistic development.

 Objectives :
  • To nourish fragile minds of children with age specific value based education and help them live life to the fullest
  • To help them blossom into expressive, fearless and beautiful individuals
  • To help them interact confidently with the children from other main stream schools, so as to bridge the gap between the affluent and poor.
  • To nurture their inborn talents and help them blossom as artists. 

What is Life Art Education? (www.lifeart.education)

The purpose of education is to prepare a child to face life’s challenges. The school is the first external exposure for a child as he/she develops physically, emotionally, and intellectually.  It is in these formative years the child learns communication skills, interpersonal relations, wholesome values, emotional maturity and more.

 Life Art Education is India's pioneering  school based Life Skills Program from eAmbalam, Chennai, designed by eminent personalities in the educational field. Life Art Education is for Children between the age group of 4 and 18 years studying from LKG to 12th standard. This would engage and involve every student in the school.

Life Art Education includes four  age-old empowerment domains:

  • Music
  • Dance
  • Yoga
  • Meditation & Personality Development.

Life Art Education program is integrated into the schools timetable.  So along with regular sciences and languages a student would have music, dance, yoga, meditation and personality development – the four  Life Art Education domains– as subjects on a weekly basis. 

With a trained faculty specially chosen for their expertise in these domains, the Life Art Education is not an adhoc intervention but a sustained yearlong initiative. It is measurable, goal driven and there is an active interaction with parents, teachers, and the students themselves.

To reiterate the objective of Life Art Education is to mould a student capable of taking decisions and handling stress through introducing music, dance, yoga, meditation, and personality development in the classroom through a structured syllabus and specially trained teaching faculty.

About eAmbalam (www.eambalam.com)

eAmbalam is the world's first Online College of Indian Classical Music, Dance, Yoga and Meditation. eAmbalam has a track record of service to the community in performing arts education for 26 years. It trains students across the world through its online portal and also runs a successful K-12 program Life Art Education for schools.

About CWDR (www.cwdr.org)

The Center for Women's Development and Research (CWDR) was founded in 1993 by a group of female activists to counter the lack of NGOs for women led by women. They recognized the importance of female-led organizations to improve women's issues.

CWDR's goal was to serve marginalized, vulnerable communities of women in the slums of Chennai and surrounding communities. Through education, organization, and advocacy, CWDR focuses on empowering three populations in particular: domestic workers, single women, and adolescent girls.

CWDR has grown substantially in size and scope since 1993 and now serves close to 100 slums in Chennai city and 25 villages in the Edaikazhinadu Panchayath Kancheepuram district. In addition CWDR has expanded its focus to include income generation projects for women such as catering, domestic worker job placement, and soapmaking. CWDR also became involved in relief efforts for women and children following the devastating tsunami in 2004.

Why is Life Art Education Community Outreach important to eAmbalam?
  • In our program run in schools we have seen proof of transformation in school children .
  • We are very excited that we are able to make a difference in their fragile lives.
  • When something wholesome is imprinted on young minds they do sprout and grow.

  •  This education should not be limited to main stream schools and should reach the not so privileged children.

  • We want to move ahead with the conviction that we will make the under-privileged and and unheard voices Sing....Dance.....Act....

  • Nurturing emotional, artistic and social skills of these children will go a long way in keeping generations happy. 

What difference you can make to this campaign ?

  • Each one of us, in our small way, can be agents of change. Your financial assistance will required to support this program. 

  • We fervently believe that no child should be left behind. The poor of our country are not poor due to lack of talent or skills but poor due to lack of opportunities. It is our motivation to see every kid raise to his/her full potential and only then the society would benefit.We plan to raise this money to support this intervention.

  • It is only our experience that students in corporate schools have higher fear, lower self-esteem, more school dropouts than elite schools.  We need your financial support on this social venture. Together we can make a real difference to the society.

  • Just as a drop of water makes the ocean, a small token of your contribution will make a definitive impact in a child's life.

How we intend to utilize the funds

We will be sending a team of 8 teachers to Kannagi Nagar and Thiruvanmiyur. These teachers are very experienced practitioners and will work closely with eAmbalam's Life Art Education in this project. eAmbalam will need to meet the resource costs, provide education material and runs assessments. Children will also be trained to be presented in a performance on a designated date in music, dance and theater.

    Other Ways You Can Help
    We would sincerely request you to
    •  get the word out by sharing this link to all your friends on Social Media
    • Talk to friends about this project
    •  use the Indiegogo share tools!
    • email us at community@eambalam.com to collaborate on a long term basis for similar ventures.

story:
Background

One would be hard pressed to find listed on a map the villages of Masson and Sarazin, villages that straddle steep mountain slopes high above Haiti's capital city, Port-au-Prince. Yet it is in these villages that an amazing transformation, at once exhilerating and deeply inspiring, is happening. A transformation through quality education, exposure to the creative arts and music, and shared values because the talent and ingenuity of a Haitian mind is too important to waste. Such are the aim and achievements of the Love and Serve Haiti Project.

Spearheaded by by two Haitian-led non-profits, the NY-based Haitian-Americans United for Progress (HAUP) and the Haiti-based Pou Solèy Leve, Love and Serve Haiti supports the schooling of some 650 children, for whom access to knowledge would otherwise be nothing but an impossible dream.

Yet Love and Serve Haiti does not stop there. It is also a transformative experience for young Americans who are challenged to affirm their leadership qualities and potential, and anchor their commitment to community with a year-long service project.

Founded some 39 years ago to promote the welfare of Haitian immigrants and refugees in the United States, HAUP is a multi-service agency that has consistently earned high marks for its delivery of services to the people of New York and Haiti. HAUP is a 501(c)3 non-profit incorporated in the State of New York. With HAUP, you can be assured that none of the funds you dedicate to Love and Serve Haiti will be redirected to other programs.

What We Need and What You Get

We have been building support all year long for the children of Masson and Sarazin through creative partnerships with fashion designers, fashion photographers, and others in the non-profit and corporate world. We are however short of the funds needed to implement fully the crucial summer school program. This includes the climatic moment -- which is fast approaching -- when the young American leaders undertake a comprehensive field visit to Haiti over a 10-day period in August. During their visit, they are exposed to Haitian history, culture and politics get to interact with the children, learning as much from them as they impart to them.

We need to raise $20,000 by this July 30, 2013.

We are turning to you for this leg of the journey. Your contribution of $10, $25, $50, $100 or more will have a significant impact on the welfare of the children of Masson and Sarazin in Haiti.

And if you so desire, we would be happy to take you along on a planned trip. You would see for yourself what Ford Model Monica Watkins or fashion photographer Kareem Black experienced when they huffed and puffed their way for an hour up the mountain slope to the school of Masson.  As they found out, climbing up was no catwalk. More importantly they realized that the real challenge for the children lay not in the daily walk but in staying the course, opening up their mind to the creative possibilities imparted by knowledge, and climbing Haiti's steep social ladder out of chronic poverty.

By providing funds to maintain and upgrade the facilities, cover teacher salaries, meals and experiential activities, we do our best to facilitate their staying the course. We are inviting you to come along with a financial contribution that is both challenging and within your means.

story:
Short Summary

A volcanic eruption blasts 40 feet into the air, splattering the facades of downtown Johnson City with the effervescing lava. The eruption—a science experiment involving carbon dioxide, surface tension, and pressure —is met with peals of laughter and exclamations of delight from the on-looking, wide-eyed children. “Awesome!...How does it work? Can we make it reach higher?”

The purpose of Hands On! Regional Museum is to get kids asking these types of questions. Now it is time for grown-ups to ask the same questions. How does it work, and can we reach even higher?

Hands On! Regional Museum has been open for over 25 years serving children and their families with interactive permanent exhibits and programming that inspires discovery and understanding of science and the arts.  70,000+ guests from our region and beyond visit Hands On! each year and we want to keep them coming back!

This summer, we are asking the community for support and launching a Focused Giving Campaign to sustain and stabilize the museum’s annual operations.  In five years we would like to serve the region from a new facility and this is the first step on that path!  Your gift will help us reach our goals!

What We Need & What You Get

Many people may not realize that it costs $11 per visitor to operate the museum but Hands On! only charges $8 for general admission and reduced or even free rates are available for those who qualify, leaving the museum with a shortfall for each and every visitor.   It is a goal of the museum that every child can visit with his or her family or school group, regardless of that family’s ability to pay.

Did you know that for our facility the utility costs (for gas, electric, and water) are $500 each week? Our staff works hard to keep costs as low as possible and to be good stewards of our donors’ money but many costs aren’t negotiable – insurance, employee costs, utilities, etc. – are all a part of our business.  The average cost to install a new exhibit is $300 per square foot!  Exhibits have to be highly specialized to be safe for our visitors and very durable to withstand the many hands that touch them each year. 

Every dollar we raise helps supplement these operational costs and allows us to keep our admission prices low and offer reduced and free admissions. 

Your support fulfills our mission: to inspire discovery and understanding of science and the arts in a place where learning and fun go hand in hand.  A child experiencing the joy of hands-on learning is the first step toward a love of life-long learning.  An investment in Hands On! is an investment in our community and the next generation.

As you can see, our donor benefits are based on providing educational, hands-on learning opportunities to children – free passes and annual memberships.  As a donor, you can keep these for your family or give them to someone who would value a visit to Hands On!  Even one exciting experience can make a difference in the life of a child.  We have had visitors tell us they loved our Cessna 150 airplane so much that they decided to be a pilot and that our Amazing Me (health) exhibit helped a mother explain to a small child what caused the grandfather’s heart attack and why exercise and healthy eating would help him recover.  These are just two example of how Hands On! makes a difference in the lives of the children we serve.

The Impact

On a community level, attendance is expected to reach 75,000 this fiscal year.  Hands On! has become a destination for children both with their friends and families as well as school groups.  Each year, the museum sees families visiting from nearly all 50 states and school groups from a 40 county area in Tennessee, Virginia, North Carolina, and Kentucky.  This makes an economic impact on our community as well as promoting downtown revitalization and increasing tourism dollars as visitors to Hands On! stop to eat, enjoy other amenities, buy gas, or spend the night.

Hands On! is not only a treasured part of the downtown community, it is a part of what it means to grow up in this area. The museum holds a special place in the childhood memories of thousands of individuals across our region. After 25 years of operation, former visitors are visiting again with children of their own. While many of the exhibits are different, there are still a few old favorites and the joy and excitement of a Hands On! visit is still found every day. 

Sustaining and growing the museum to serve new generations is the best tribute that can be made to the Hands On! legacy.  The families in this region deserve a Hands On! Regional Museum.  At Hands On!, we envision serving this community from a new facility within 5 years—a goal we can meet with your help. The first step is getting a solid foundation of operational support on which to build.

Other Ways You Can Help

We all have a hand in the future of our community, and we have the opportunity to do something very exciting if we work together.  Even if you can’t donate money, donate your time!  You can spread the word about this campaign and how much you love Hands On!

Share this campaign with your friends, stop by and pick up a yard sign, get a bumper sticker, purchase a paper hand from our front desk for only $1!  Or just visit the museum and enjoy the day! 

Thank you very much for taking the time to read about our cause!  We hope you will decide to donate today!  Every gift counts!!

If you are interested in other giving opportunities, please contact us at (423) 434-HAND (4263)!

story:
Thanks for anything you have done to help my son succeed by investing in his future... It means everything to me.

The impact on my son's life will be endless. His degree and success will empower him to help his family and experience the world.    

 “To accomplish great things, we must not only act, but also dream; not only plan, but also believe.” ~ Anatole France

story:
What in the world were we doing?

Education and awareness facilitated by the international language of music is one of the best ways to reach underprivileged and rural communities in Cambodia. The goal of the Opening Doors Countryside Tour of Cambodia is to promote awareness and educate community members about child sexual abuse and exploitation and its impact on the victims and their families in an approachable way that is easy to communicate and understand - supported by concerts from the Kampot Playboys and Friends featuring Khmer and international music; helping families, children and leaders to keep their communities safe.

April 7, 2013, Where are we today?

On April 5, the first of two Opening Doors Countryside sessions took place in Snom Prampy Secondary School near Kampot. In blistering heat, 120 [60M/60F] interested and motivated students listened to the lessons about the impact of sexual abuse and exploitation, how to recognize suspicious behaviors and where and how to report abuse and to seek for protection, which was explained and conducted by two members of APLE Sihanoukville's investigation team. All students received information cards with a summary of the lessons learned and a t-shirt with the phone-numbers from APLE and the Anti-Human Trafficking and Juvenile Protection Police. After the training the participants and other villagers were treated with a joyful performance of Khmer rock 'n' roll by The Kampot Playboys.
The whole campaign was being made possible by the donations from 33 private donors from all over the world. On behalf of the villages we visited, APLE and The Kampot Playboys say THANK YOU to all donors for making this possible. Today we will visit Prey Khmum village and pictures of that event will follow tomorrow.

On April 6, APLE and The Kampot Playboys brought the Opening Doors Countryside Tour to Prey Khmum village at the foot of Phnom Sor Mountain. After a funny welcome speech by the commune chief, who stayed and enjoyed until the almost end of the event, the training started in which 100 invited secondary school students [46M/54F] and 20 community leaders and teachers [10M/10F] participated. Although the annual Khmer New Year holiday already had started, the commune chief and the head school master made the students return to school for one day to be educated about all aspects of child sexual abuse and exploitation and related issues. Additionally, another 40 village kids joined the event. Following the educational session was another groovy set of rock ‘n’ roll by The Kampot Playboys, which even made the chief monk of the nearby pagoda tap his feet on the ground.

We want to say thanks here once more to all the people that have donated so far: Christine Chattaway, Sheila Robson, Sandra Young, Sebastian Schaefer, Rohan Jackson, Esther Martinez Teruel, S.Zimmermann, G.Neunhoeffer, Marc Gold, Tom Gee, Thierry Darnaudet, Hannah Cherill, Catherine Gee, Joanna Corzo, Zoe Linch, Derrick Dennis, Heide Deter, Gillian Sutherland, Birka Schmidt, Theresia Alt, Marc Bergweiler, Dennis Ringersma, Liz Forth, Veronika Schmid, Denise Robertson, Dave Makepeace, Neal Chattaway, Fionn Quinlan, Ry-Ann Lim, John Chattaway, Yvonne & Peter Kimber, Hillary Dean, John Sefton, Emily Churchill, Beryl & Keith Jubb, Marie Klang, Henrik Gillingstam, Eric M. Karatau, Marc Korsikowski, Ina Richter and some donors who preferred to stay anonyous.

 

Why were we doing this?

After having been on a theatre performance tour in rural villages in Cambodia with Canadian theatre and dance group Corpus, late 2011, and a musical concert series, early 2012, with local and western performers, including Mr. Conrad Keely from US rock band And You Will Know Us By The Trail Of Dead, the idea was born among the participating artists to do similar events more often, and to combine entertainment and culture with more serious matters to create a project that can be of great benefit to local communities. With the signs of child sexual abuse and exploitation being so obvious in Cambodia, it was the logical topic to pick and to say: we want to do something against it and prevent it, to make it stop. We regularly would like to do a series of concerts by Cambodian and foreign artists, reaching communities that normally have no access to cultural activities and modern arts. 

Due to Cambodia's high poverty rate many children in Cambodia are vulnerable to sexual abuse and exploitation. Additionally, cultural specificities, such as the traditionally valued honour and reputation of the family and the desire to maintain harmony above all, contribute to a “culture of silence” surrounding child sexual abuse and it creates a climate where child abuse and exploitation can exist and grow. APLE believes that an informed and educated community is the best defense against child sexual abuse. To achieve this APLE works together with police and community leaders to spread information about how to recognize abuser's approaches, prevent sexual abuse from happening, and report suspected incidents through village meetings, performances, awareness and training, and advertising, all emphasizing prevention.

Who are we?

APLE Cambodia - Action Pour Les Enfants is a Cambodia-based advocacy group operating since 2003. APLE's work has led to the arrest and subsequent prosecution of more than 243 child sex offenders (155 successful convictions, 25 cases still pending) and has tirelessly provided social and legal support and counseling for more than 600 victims and their families. In addition, APLE provided thousands of street-children with education about sexual abuse. APLE also works with the Cambodian government and international law enforcement agencies advising on how to minimize loopholes in the existing laws and creating new legislation so that offenders may be more effectively prosecuted, providing justice and protection for the victims. 

The Kampot Playboys exist out of four core members and a collective of varying Khmer and non-Cambodian musicians, who play traditional Cambodian music with influences from Irish folk, Americana, rock and punk. The reason to be involved in the project is to get out of the white bubble entertainment venues and to give something back to the communities and the country where everybody currently loves to live and work and/or is having families..


What did we do with Project Documentation?

We filmed the awareness and training activities as well as the concerts. This footage was turned into a short documentary which you can see at the top of this page. This production will also be used as awareness, promotion, and fundraising tool for future projects.

 How were we using funds?

At the bottom of this page you can find detailed tables with the amount of money donated and the expenditures.

We would love to do an additional tour later in the year.

Other Ways You Can Help With This

Everyone can help, here is how:

  • Please help us spread the word and we'll be eternally grateful!
  • Awareness and education are the best ways to prevent abuse - arm yourself with knowledge!
  • You can keep donating to do a similar event at any time. Find French and Cambodian banking details on www.aplecambodia.org or regularly posted on APLE's timeline on www.facebook.com/aple.cambodia Don't forget to write down as reason for payment: OPENING DOORS

Please join us and help us reach our goal. Thank you in advance for your support and please spread the word around the world. 

Arkun Chran - Thank you very much!

story_txt:
What in the world were we doing?
Education and awareness facilitated by the international language of music is one of the best ways to reach underprivileged and rural communities in Cambodia. The goal of the Opening Doors Countryside Tour of Cambodia is to promote awareness and educate community members about child sexual abuse and exploitation and its impact on the victims and their families in an approachable way that is easy to communicate and understand - supported by concerts from the Kampot Playboys and Friends featuring Khmer and international music; helping families, children and leaders to keep their communities safe.

April 7, 2013, Where are we today?
On April 5, the first of two Opening Doors Countryside sessions took place in Snom Prampy Secondary School near Kampot. In blistering heat, 120 [60M/60F] interested and motivated students listened to the lessons about the impact of sexual abuse and exploitation, how to recognize suspicious behaviors and where and how to report abuse and to seek for protection, which was explained and conducted by two members of APLE Sihanoukville's investigation team. All students received information cards with a summary of the lessons learned and a t-shirt with the phone-numbers from APLE and the Anti-Human Trafficking and Juvenile Protection Police. After the training the participants and other villagers were treated with a joyful performance of Khmer rock 'n' roll by The Kampot Playboys.The whole campaign was being made possible by the donations from 33 private donors from all over the world. On behalf of the villages we visited, APLE and The Kampot Playboys say THANK YOU to all donors for making this possible. Today we will visit Prey Khmum village and pictures of that event will follow tomorrow.

On April 6, APLE and The Kampot Playboys brought the Opening Doors Countryside Tour to Prey Khmum village at the foot of Phnom Sor Mountain. After a funny welcome speech by the commune chief, who stayed and enjoyed until the almost end of the event, the training started in which 100 invited secondary school students [46M/54F] and 20 community leaders and teachers [10M/10F] participated. story:
Antonia's Journey Home

Our dear friend Nina is a gifted and kind Special Education teacher in a public school in New York City. For the many years we have known her, adopting a child has always been the way she wanted to build a family.  Throughout the past few years, we, her colleagues and friends, have watched Nina work diligently to find the right agency and area of the world to adopt from.

When we finally got to see a photo of Nina's match, we all rejoiced and shed tears, knowing how lucky the two of them would soon be.  Nina's home will be a wonderful place for a child to learn and grow.

Her commitment to bringing a child from an impoverished country into her home has come, however, with many challenges for the past few years.  From agency fees to travel expenses, her adoption costs near $50,000.  Unlike childbirth, adoption does not receive benefits.  The financial burdens are solely on the mother.  While Nina and we are happy that the adoption is happening faster than expected, it has made it harder to gather funds.

One of the last, and most exciting, parts of her adoption will be getting Antonia home.   We would all like to be a part of her safe and comfortable journey to New York, and we are asking for your help.

The cost of travel expenses and unpaid foreign fees near $12,000.

Nina's blog outlines the beauty and struggle of Antonia's journey home.  She hopes to be of support and guidance to prospective parents for future adoptions.

Any contribution to this beautiful little girl's journey home would be greatly appreciated.

Updates to come:
As soon as Antonia is home, we will be able to post photos of Nina and Antonia together.  To protect Antonia's privacy and the adoption, we cannot yet share specifics.  However, we are expecting the journey home to be complete soon, and will post photos and details about her age, birth country, personality, and her new home as soon as the adoption agency permits it.

Message from Nina, and links:

From the beginning of this process through this moment right now, one sentiment has been present:  humbling.  Love and worry have grown, patience has waned, but this feeling of humility has been present throughout. From the first class on parenting to sitting down with friends to write this, I am humbled.  Their kindness is touching.

I have remarkably special people in my life.  Antonia and I are very fortunate.  However, we are in a financially precarious position.  I love my friends for working to ease this for us.  We are eternally grateful.

Our story can be found at http://ninaadopts.blogspot.com/
